n

amicably
In an amicable manner.
adv

amice
A square of white linen worn at first on the head but now about the neck and shoulders by priests of the Roman Catholic Church while saying Mass;  A hood or cape with a hood made of lined with gray fur formerly worn by the clergy; -- written also amess amyss and almuce.
n

amid
See Amidst.
prep

amide
A compound formed by the union of amidogen with an acid element or radical. It may also be regarded as ammonia in which one or more hydrogen atoms have been replaced by an acid atom or radical.
n

amidin
Start modified by heat so as to become a transparent mass like horn. It is soluble in cold water.
n

amido
Containing or derived from amidogen.
adj

amidogen
A compound radical NH2 not yet obtained in a separate state which may be regarded as ammonia from the molecule of which one of its hydrogen atoms has been removed; -- called also the amido group and in composition represented by the form amido.
n

amidol
A salt of a diamino phenol C6H3(OH)(NH2)2 used as a developer.
n

amidships
In the middle of a ship with regard to her length and sometimes also her breadth.
adv

amidst
In the midst or middle of; surrounded or encompassed by; among.
prep

amigo
A friend; -- a Spanish term applied in the Philippine Islands to friendly natives.
n

amine
One of a class of basic substances derived from ammonia by replacement of one or more hydrogen atoms by an alkyl or aryl group. Compare amide in which an acyl group is attached to the nitrogen. Hydroxylamine and hydrazine which are not an organic compounds are also basic and may also be considered amines.
n

aminoalkane
a compound derived from ammonia by replacing hydrogen atoms by univalent hydrocarbon radicals.
n

aminobenzine
an oily poisonous liquid amine obtained from nitrobenzene and used to make dyes and plastics and medicines. Same as aniline.
n

aminol
A colorless liquid prepared from herring brine and containing amines used as a local antiseptic.
n

aminomethane
a methyl with the hydrogen atom replaced by an amino radical.
n

aminopyrine
a white crystalline substance used as an analgesic and antipyretic.
n

amioid
Like or pertaining to the Amioidei.
adj

amioidei
An order of ganoid fishes of which Amia is the type. See Bowfin and Ganoidei.
n

amir
Same as Ameer.
n

amish
The Amish Mennonites;  Of pertaining to or designating the followers of Jacob Amman a strict Mennonite of the 17th century who even proscribed the use of buttons and shaving as “worldly conformity”. There are several branches of Amish Mennonites in the United States. A branch having particularly strict adherence to the Amish principles are called Old Order Amish.
n

amiss
Astray; faultily; improperly; wrongly; ill;  Wrong; faulty; out of order; improper; as it may not be amiss to ask advice;  A fault wrong or mistake.
adv

amissibility
The quality of being amissible; possibility of being lost.
misc

amissible
Liable to be lost.
adj

amission
Deprivation; loss.
n

amit
To lose.
v

amitosis
Cell division in which there is first a simple cleavage of the nucleus without change in its structure (such as the formation of chromosomes) followed by the division of the cytoplasm; direct cell division; -- opposed to mitosis. It is not the usual mode of division and is believed by many to occur chiefly in highly specialized cells which are incapable of long-continued multiplication in transitory structures and in those in early stages of degeneration.
n

amitotic
Of or pertaining to amitosis; karyostenotic; -- opposed to mitotic.
adj

amity
Friendship in a general sense between individuals societies or nations; friendly relations; good understanding; as a treaty of amity and commerce; the amity of the Whigs and Tories.
n

amma
An abbes or spiritual mother.
n

ammeter
A contraction of amperometer or amperemeter.
n

ammiral
An obsolete form of admiral.
n

ammite
Oolite or roestone; -- written also hammite.
n

ammobium
any plant of the genus Ammobium having yellow flowers and silvery foliage.
n

ammodyte
One of a genus of fishes; the sand eel.
n

ammodytes
type genus of the Ammodytidae.
n

ammodytidae
a family comprising the sand lances.
n

ammonal
An explosive consisting of a mixture of powdered aluminum and ammonium nitrate.
n

ammonia
A gaseous compound of hydrogen and nitrogen NH3 with a pungent smell and taste: -- often called volatile alkali and spirits of hartshorn.
n

ammoniac
Of pertaining or containing ammonia or possessing its properties; as an ammoniac salt; ammoniacal gas;  The concrete juice (gum resin) of an umbelliferous plant the Dorema ammoniacum. It is brought chiefly from Persia in the form of yellowish tears which occur singly or are aggregated into masses. It has a peculiar smell and a nauseous sweet taste followed by a bitter one. It is inflammable partially soluble in water and in spirit of wine and is used in medicine as an expectorant and resolvent and for the formation of certain plasters.
adj

ammoniacal-fermentation
Any fermentation process by which ammonia is formed as that by which urea is converted into ammonium carbonate when urine is exposed to the air.
misc

ammoniate
treat with ammonia; expose to ammonia.
v

ammoniated
Combined or impregnated with ammonia.
adj

ammonic
Of or pertaining to ammonia.
adj

ammonite
A fossil cephalopod shell related to the nautilus. There are many genera and species and all are extinct the typical forms having existed only in the Mesozoic age when they were exceedingly numerous. They differ from the nautili in having the margins of the septa very much lobed or plaited and the siphuncle dorsal. Also called serpent stone snake stone and cornu Ammonis.
n

ammonitiferous
Containing fossil ammonites.
adj

ammonitoidea
An extensive group of fossil cephalopods often very abundant in Mesozoic rocks. See Ammonite.
n

ammonium
A compound radical NH4 having the chemical relations of a strongly basic element like the alkali metals.
n

ammonoid
one of the coiled chambered fossil shells of extinct mollusks; same as ammonite.
n

ammotragus
a genus of wild sheep.
n

ammunition
Military stores or provisions of all kinds for attack or defense;  Articles used in charging firearms and ordnance of all kinds; as powder balls shot shells percussion caps rockets etc;  Any stock of missiles literal or figurative;  To provide with ammunition.
n

amnesia
Forgetfulness; also a defect of speech from cerebral disease in which the patient substitutes wrong words or names in the place of those he wishes to employ.
n

amnesiac
Having lost memories especially due to brain injury or mental shock; suffering from amnesia.
adj

amnesic
Of or pertaining to amnesia;  Same as amnesiac.
adj

amnestic
Causing loss of memory.
adj

amnesty
Forgetfulness; cessation of remembrance of wrong; oblivion;  An act of the sovereign power granting oblivion or a general pardon for a past offense as to subjects concerned in an insurrection;  To grant amnesty to.
n

amnicolist
One who lives near a river.
n

amnigenous
Born or bred in of or near a river.
adj

amnion
A thin membrane surrounding the embryos of mammals birds and reptiles.
n

amnios
Same as Amnion.
n

amniota
That group of vertebrates which develops in its embryonic life the envelope called the amnion. It comprises the reptiles the birds and the mammals.
n

amniote
any member of the Amniota.
n

amniotic
Of or pertaining to the amnion; characterized by an amnion; as the amniotic fluid; the amniotic sac.
adj

amoeba
A rhizopod common in fresh water capable of undergoing many changes of form at will. Same as ameba. See Rhizopoda.
n

amoebaeum
A poem in which persons are represented at speaking alternately; as the third and seventh eclogues of Virgil.
n

amoebea
That division of the Rhizopoda which includes the amoeba and similar forms.
n

amoebean
Alternately answering.
adj

amoebian
One of the Amoebea.
n

amoebiform
Resembling an amoeba; amoeba-shaped; changing in shape like an amoeba.
adj

amoebous
Like an amoeba in structure.
adj

amole
Any detergent plant or the part of it used as a detergent as the roots of Agave Americana Chlorogalum pomeridianum etc.

n

amomum
A genus of aromatic plants. It includes species which bear cardamoms and grains of paradise.
n

amoneste

v

among

the ancient Egyptian sun god; supreme god of the universe in whom Amen and Ra were combined; principal deity during Theban supremacy.

n

amorphism
A state of being amorphous; esp. a state of being without crystallization even in the minutest particles as in glass opal etc.
n

amorphophallus
any plant of the genus Amorphophallus.
n

amorphous
Having no determinate form; of irregular; shapeless;  Without crystallization in the ultimate texture of a solid substance; uncrystallized;  Of no particular kind or character; anomalous.

Animals without a mouth or regular internal organs as the sponges.

As if dead; lifeless; spiritless; dejected; depressed.

misc

To make as if dead; to destroy;  To alienate in mortmain that is to convey to a corporation. See Mortmain;  To clear off or extinguish as a debt usually by means of a sinking fund.
v

amount
To go up; to ascend;  To rise or reach by an accumulation of particular sums or quantities; to come (to) in the aggregate or whole; -- with to or unto;  To rise reach or extend in effect substance or influence; to be equivalent; to come practically (to); as the testimony amounts to very little;  To signify; to amount to;  The sum total of two or more sums or quantities; the aggregate; the whole quantity; a totality; as the amount of 7 and 9 is 16; the amount of a bill; the amount of this year's revenue; The effect substance value significance or result; the sum; as the amount of the testimony is this.

amour
Love; affection;  Love making; a love affair; usually an unlawful connection in love; a love intrigue; an illicit love affair.

amovability
Liability to be removed or dismissed from office.
n

amovable
Removable.
adj

amove
To remove as a person or thing from a position;  To dismiss from an office or station;  To move or be moved; to excite.
v

ampelite
An earth abounding in pyrites used by the ancients to kill insects etc. on vines; -- applied by Brongniart to a carbonaceous alum schist.
n

ampelopsis
A genus formerly including the Virginia creeper.
n

amperage
The strength of a current of electricity carried by a conductor or generated by a machine measured in amperes.
n

ampere
The unit of electric current; -- defined by the International Electrical Congress in 1893 and by U. S. Statute as one tenth of the unit of current of the C. G. S. system of electro-magnetic units or the practical equivalent of the unvarying current which when passed through a standard solution of nitrate of silver in water deposits silver at the rate of 0.001118 grams per second. Called also the international ampere.
n

ampere-foot
A unit employed in calculating fall of pressure in distributing mains equivalent to a current of one ampere flowing through one foot of conductor.
misc

ampere-hour
The quantity of electricity delivered in one hour by a current whose average strength is one ampere. It is used as a unit of quantity and is equal to 3600 coulombs. The terms Ampere minute and Ampere second are sometimes similarly used.
misc

amperemeter
An instrument for measuring the strength of an electrical current in amperes.
n

ampere-second
a unit of charge equal to that acquired by the accumulation of one ampere for one second.
n

ampere-turn
A unit of magnetomotive force equal to the product of one complete convolution (of a coiled conductor) into one ampere of current; thus a conductor having five convolutions and carrying a current of half an ampere is said to have 212 ampere turns. The magnetizing effect of a coil is proportional to the number of its ampere turns.
misc

ampersand
A word used to describe the character � � or &.
n

amphi-
A prefix in words of Greek origin signifying both of both kinds on both sides about around.
misc

amphiarthrodial
Characterized by amphiarthrosis.
adj

amphiarthrosis
A form of articulation in which the bones are connected by intervening substance admitting slight motion; symphysis.
n

amphiaster
The achromatic figure formed in mitotic cell-division consisting of two asters connected by a spindle-shaped bundle of rodlike fibers diverging from each aster and called the spindle.
n

amphibia
One of the classes of vertebrates.
n

amphibial
Amphibian.
adj

amphibian
Of or pertaining to the Amphibia; as amphibian reptiles;  One of the Amphibia.
adj

amphibiological
Pertaining to amphibiology.
adj

amphibiology
A treatise on amphibious animals; the department of natural history which treats of the Amphibia.
n

amphibiotica
A division of insects having aquatic larvae.
n

amphibious
Having the ability to live both on land and in water as frogs crocodiles beavers and some plants;  Pertaining to adapted for or connected with both land and water;  Of a mixed nature; partaking of two natures.
adj

amphibiously
Like an amphibious being.
adv

amphibium
An amphibian.
n

amphiblastic
Segmenting unequally; -- said of telolecithal ova with complete segmentation.
adj

amphibole
A common mineral embracing many varieties varying in color and in composition. It occurs in monoclinic crystals; also massive generally with fibrous or columnar structure. The color varies from white to gray green brown and black. It is a silicate of magnesium and calcium with usually aluminium and iron. Some common varieties are tremolite actinolite asbestus edenite hornblende (the last name being also used as a general term for the whole species). Amphibole is a constituent of many crystalline rocks as syenite diorite most varieties of trachyte etc. See Hornblende.
n

amphibolic
Of or pertaining to amphiboly; ambiguous; equivocal;  Of or resembling the mineral amphibole.
adj

amphibolite
a metamorphic rock composed chiefly of amphibole and plagioclase.
n

amphibological
Of doubtful meaning; ambiguous.
adj

amphibology
A phrase discourse or proposition susceptible of two interpretations; and hence of uncertain meaning. It differs from equivocation which arises from the twofold sense of a single term;  Ambiguous; doubtful;  Capable of two meanings.
n

amphiboly
Ambiguous discourse; amphibology.
n

amphibrach
A foot of three syllables the middle one long the first and last short (˘ -- ˘); as hăbērĕ. In modern prosody the accented syllable takes the place of the long and the unaccented of the short; as pro-phet"ic.
n

amphicarpic
Producing fruit of two kinds either as to form or time of ripening.
adj

amphichroic
Exhibiting or producing two colors as substances which in the color test may change red litmus to blue and blue litmus to red.
adj

amphicoelian
Having both ends concave; biconcave; -- said of vertebrae.
adj

amphicome
A kind of figured stone rugged and beset with eminences anciently used in divination.
n

amphictyonic
Of or pertaining to the Amphictyons or their League or Council; as an Amphictyonic town or state; the Amphictyonic body.
adj

amphictyons
Deputies from the confederated states of ancient Greece to a congress or council. They considered both political and religious matters.
n

amphictyony
A league of states of ancient Greece; esp. the celebrated confederation known as the Amphictyonic Council. Its object was to maintain the common interests of Greece.
n

amphid
A salt of the class formed by the combination of an acid and a base or by the union of two oxides two sulphides selenides or tellurides as distinguished from a haloid compound.
n

amphidisc
A peculiar small siliceous spicule having a denticulated wheel at each end; -- found in freshwater sponges.
n

amphidromical
Pertaining to an Attic festival at the naming of a child; -- so called because the friends of the parents carried the child around the hearth and then named it.
adj

amphigamous
Having a structure entirely cellular and no distinct sexual organs; -- a term applied by De Candolle to the lowest order of plants.
adj

amphigean
Extending over all the zones from the tropics to the polar zones inclusive.
adj

amphigen
An element that in combination produces amphid salt; -- applied by Berzelius to oxygen sulphur selenium and tellurium.
n

amphigene
Leucite.
n

amphigenesis
Sexual generation; amphigony.
n

amphigenous
Increasing in size by growth on all sides as the lichens.
adj

amphigonic
Pertaining to amphigony; sexual; as amphigonic propagation.
adj

amphigonous
Relating to both parents.
adj

amphigony
Sexual propagation.

amphigoric
Nonsensical; absurd; pertaining to an amphigory.
adj

amphigory
A nonsense verse; a rigmarole with apparent meaning which on further attention proves to be meaningless.
n

Ambiguity of speech; equivocation.
n

amphimacer
A foot of three syllables the middle one short and the others long as in cāst�tās.
n

amphineura
A division of Mollusca remarkable for the bilateral symmetry of the organs and the arrangement of the nerves.
n

amphioxidae
a family comprising the lancelets.
n

amphioxus
A fishlike creature (Amphioxus lanceolatus) two or three inches long found in temperature seas; -- also called the lancelet. Its body is pointed at both ends. It is the lowest and most generalized of the vertebrates having neither brain skull vertebrae nor red blood. It forms the type of the group Acrania Leptocardia etc.
n

amphipneust
One of a tribe of Amphibia which have both lungs and gills at the same time as the proteus and siren.
n

amphipod
One of the Amphipoda;  Of or pertaining to the Amphipoda.
n

amphipoda
A numerous group of fourteen -- footed Crustacea inhabiting both fresh and salt water. The body is usually compressed laterally and the anterior pairs or legs are directed downward and forward but the posterior legs are usually turned upward and backward. The beach flea is an example. See Tetradecapoda and Arthrostraca.
n

amphipodous
Of or pertaining to the Amphipoda.
adj

amphiprostylar
having columns at both ends but not on the sides.
adj

amphiprostyle
Doubly prostyle; having columns at each end but not at the sides.
adj

amphirhina
A name applied to the elasmobranch fishes because the nasal sac is double.
n

amphisbaena
A fabled serpent with a head at each end moving either way;  A genus of harmless lizards serpentlike in form without legs and with both ends so much alike that they appear to have a head at each and ability to move either way. See Illustration in Appendix.
n

amphisbaenoid
Like or pertaining to the lizards of the genus Amphisbaena.
adj

amphiscii
The inhabitants of the tropic whose shadows in one part of the year are cast to the north and in the other to the south according as the sun is south or north of their zenith.
n

amphistomous
Having a sucker at each extremity as certain entozoa by means of which they adhere.
adj

amphistylic
Having the mandibular arch articulated with the hyoid arch and the cranium as in the cestraciont sharks; -- said of a skull.
adj

amphitheater
An oval or circular building with rising tiers of seats about an open space called the arena;  Anything resembling an amphitheater in form; as a level surrounded by rising slopes or hills or a rising gallery in a theater.
n

amphitheatral
Amphitheatrical; resembling an amphitheater.
adj

adv

amphitrocha
A kind of annelid larva having both a dorsal and a ventral circle of special cilia.
n

amphitropal
Having the ovule inverted but with the attachment near the middle of one side; half anatropous.
adj

amphiuma
A genus of amphibians inhabiting the Southern United States having a serpentlike form but with four minute limbs and two persistent gill openings; the Congo snake.
n

amphopeptone
A product of gastric digestion a mixture of hemipeptone and antipeptone.
n

amphora
Among the ancients a two-handled vessel tapering at the bottom used for holding wine oil etc.
n

amphoral
Pertaining to or resembling an amphora.
adj

amphoric
Produced by or indicating a cavity in the lungs not filled and giving a sound like that produced by blowing into an empty decanter; as amphoric respiration or resonance.
adj

amphoteric
Partly one and partly the other; neither acid nor alkaline; neutral.
adj

amphotericin
an antibiotic and antifungal agent (C47H73NO17) produced by a strain of Streptomyces nodosus. It is one of a class of polyene macrolide antibiotics effective against fungal infections. It has a molecular weight of 924.11; it is soluble in oganic solvents but only slightly soluble in water.
n

ampicillin
a semisynthetic penicillin which can be considered as the common benzylpenicillin containing an amino group at the alpha benzyl position.
n

ample

v

amplitude
State of being ample; extent of surface or space; largeness of dimensions; size;  Largeness in a figurative sense; breadth; abundance; fullness;  The arc of the horizon between the true east or west point and the center of the sun or a star at its rising or setting. At the rising the amplitude is eastern or ortive: at the setting it is western occiduous or occasive. It is also northern or southern when north or south of the equator;  The horizontal line which measures the distance to which a projectile is thrown; the range;  The extent of a movement measured from the starting point or position of equilibrium; -- applied especially to vibratory movements;  An angle upon which the value of some function depends; -- a term used more especially in connection with elliptic functions.
n

amply

adv

amvis
An explosive consisting of ammonium nitrate a derivative of nitrobenzene chlorated napthalene and wood meal.
n

amy
A friend.
n

amyelous
Wanting the spinal cord.
adj

amygdala
An almond;  One of the tonsils of the pharynx.
n

amygdalaceous
Akin to or derived from the almond.
adj

amygdalate
Pertaining to resembling or made of almonds;  An emulsion made of almonds; milk of almonds; A salt amygdalic acid.
adj

amygdalic
Of or pertaining to almonds; derived from amygdalin; as amygdalic acid.
adj

amygdaliferous
Almond-bearing.
adj

amygdalin
A glucoside extracted from bitter almonds as a white crystalline substance.
n

amygdaline
Of pertaining to or resembling almonds.
adj

amygdaloid
A variety of trap or basaltic rock containing small cavities occupied wholly or in part by nodules or geodes of different minerals esp. agates quartz calcite and the zeolites. When the imbedded minerals are detached or removed by decomposition it is porous like lava;  Almond-shaped; Pertaining to or having the nature of the rock amygdaloid.
n

amyl
A univalent hydrocarbon radical C5H11 of the paraffine series found in amyl alcohol or fusel oil etc.
n

amylaceous
Pertaining to starch; of the nature of starch; starchy.
adj

amyl-alcohol
Any of eight isomeric liquid alcohols (C5H11.OH) transparent colorless liquids. It is the hydroxide of amyl. Also called amylic alcohol. The amyl alcohol obtained from fusel oil is mostly isoamyl alcohol (3-methyl-1-butanol or 1-hydroxy-3-methylbutane) with some sec-amyl alcohol (2-methyl-1-butanol or 2-pentanol) and has a characteristic peculiar odor. Other than n-amyl alcohol (also called 1-pentanol) the other isomeric pentanols are not usually refered to as amyl alcohol. The amyl alcohol mixture in fusel oil forms a colorless liquid with a peculiar cough-exciting odor and burning taste. It is used as a source of amyl compounds such as amyl acetate amyl nitrite etc.
misc

amylate
A compound of the radical amyl with oxygen and a positive atom or radical.
n

amylene
One of a group of metameric hydrocarbons C5H10 of the ethylene series. The colorless volatile mobile liquid commonly called amylene is a mixture of different members of the group.
n

amylic
Pertaining to or derived from amyl; as amylic ether.
adj

amyl-nitrite
A yellowish oily volatile liquid C5H11NO2 used in medicine as a heart stimulant and a vasodilator. The inhalation of its vapor instantly produces flushing of the face.
misc

amylobacter
A microorganism (Bacillus amylobacter) which develops in vegetable tissue during putrefaction.
n

amylogen
That part of the starch granule or granulose which is soluble in water.
n

amylogenesis
The formation of starch.
n

amylogenic
Of or pertaining to amylogen;  Forming starch; -- applied specif. to leucoplasts.
adj

amyloid
Resembling or containing amyl; starchlike;  A non-nitrogenous starchy food; a starchlike substance; The substance deposited in the organs in amyloid degeneration.
adj

amyloidal
resembling starch.
adj

amyloidosis
a disorder characterized by deposit of amyloid in organs or tissues; often secondary to chronic rheumatoid arthritis or tuberculosis or multiple myeloma.
n

amylolysis
The conversion of starch into soluble products as dextrins and sugar esp. by the action of enzymes.
n

amylolytic
Effecting the conversion of starch into soluble dextrin and sugar; as an amylolytic ferment.
adj

amylometer
Instrument for determining the amount of starch in a substance.
n

amyloplastic
Starch-forming; amylogenic.
adj

amylopsin
The diastase of the pancreatic juice.
n

amylose
One of the starch group (C6H10O5)n of the carbohydrates; as starch arabin dextrin cellulose etc.
n

amyous
Wanting in muscle; without flesh.
adj

amyss
Same as Amice a hood or cape.
n

an
This word is properly an adjective but is commonly called the indefinite article. It is used before nouns of the singular number only and signifies one or any but somewhat less emphatically. In such expressions as “twice an hour” “once an age” a shilling an ounce (see 2d A 2) it has a distributive force and is equivalent to each every;  If; -- a word used by old English authors.
misc

ana
Of each; an equal quantity; as wine and honey ana (or contracted aa) � ij. that is of wine and honey each two ounces.
adv

ana-
A prefix in words from the Greek denoting up upward throughout backward back again anew.
misc

-ana
A suffix to names of persons or places used to denote a collection of notable sayings literary gossip anecdotes etc. Thus Scaligerana is a book containing the sayings of Scaliger Johnsoniana of Johnson etc.
misc

adj

adj

anabolic-steroid
any of a variety of synthetic derivatives or analogs of testosterone which promote the increase of muscle mass and strength. The anabolic steroids are sometimes used by athletes to increase muscular strength so as to enhance their performance in competition. They have serious side effects and the use of such compounds has been banned by many athletic regulatory committees.
n

anabolism
The constructive metabolism of the body as distinguished from catabolism.
n

anabranch
A branch of a river that reenters or anastomoses with the main stream; also less properly a branch which loses itself in sandy soil.
n

adj

n

adj

anacharis
A fresh-water weed of the frog's-bit family (Hydrocharidaceae) native to America. Transferred to England it became an obstruction to navigation. Called also waterweed and water thyme.

adj

A misplacing or error in the order of time; an error in chronology by which events are misplaced in regard to each other esp. one by which an event is placed too early; falsification of chronological relation.
n

n

adj

n

anaconda
A large South American snake of the Boa family (Eunectes murinus) which lives near rivers and preys on birds and small mammals. The name is also applied to a similar large serpent (Python tigris) of Ceylon.

n

anadiplosis
A repetition of the last word or any prominent word in a sentence or clause at the beginning of the next with an adjunct idea; as “He retained his virtues amidst all his misfortunes -- misfortunes which no prudence could foresee or prevent.”.
n

anadrom
A fish that leaves the sea and ascends rivers.

adj

anaerobia
Anaerobic bacteria. They are called facultative anaerobes when able to live either in the presence or absence of free oxygen; obligate anaerobes or obligatory anaerobes when they thrive only in its absence.
n

anaerobic
Not requiring air or oxygen for life; -- applied especially to those microbes to which free oxygen is unnecessary; anaerobiotic; -- opposed to aerobic;  Relating to or like anaerobies; anaerobiotic.
adj

anaerobies
Microorganisms which do not require oxygen but are killed by it. See obligate anaerobes under anaerobes.
n

anaerobiotic
Related to or of the nature of anaerobies.

n

anagram
Literally the letters of a word read backwards but in its usual wider sense the change of one word or phrase into another by the transposition of its letters. Thus Galenus becomes angelus; William Noy (attorney-general to Charles I. and a laborious man) may be turned into I moyl in law;  To anagrammatize.

A white or flesh-red mineral of the zeolite family occurring in isometric crystals. By friction it acquires a weak electricity; hence its name.

analemma
An orthographic projection of the sphere on the plane of the meridian the eye being supposed at an infinite distance and in the east or west point of the horizon;  An instrument of wood or brass on which this projection of the sphere is made having a movable horizon or cursor; -- formerly much used in solving some common astronomical problems;  A scale of the sun's declination for each day of the year drawn across the torrid zone on an artificial terrestrial globe.

analepsis
Recovery of strength after sickness.

Restorative; giving strength after disease.

analgen
A crystalline compound used as an antipyretic and analgesic employed chiefly in rheumatism and neuralgia. It is a complex derivative of quinoline.

serving to reduce the sensibility to pain without loss of consciousness;  a medication which serves to reduce the sensibility to pain without loss of consciousness. Aspirin and acetaminophen (Tylenol) are commonly used non-prescription analgesics.

v

analogon
Analogue.
n

analogous
Having analogy; corresponding to something else; bearing some resemblance or proportion; -- often followed by to.
adj

analogue
That which is analogous to or corresponds with some other thing;  A word in one language corresponding with one in another; an analogous term; as the Latin “pater” is the analogue of the English “father.”;  An organ which is equivalent in its functions to a different organ in another species or group or even in the same group; as the gill of a fish is the analogue of a lung in a quadruped although the two are not of like structural relations.
n

analogy
A resemblance of relations; an agreement or likeness between things in some circumstances or effects when the things are otherwise entirely different. Thus learning enlightens the mind because it is to the mind what light is to the eye enabling it to discover things before hidden;  A relation or correspondence in function between organs or parts which are decidedly different;  Proportion; equality of ratios;  Conformity of words to the genius structure or general rules of a language; similarity of origin inflection or principle of pronunciation and the like as opposed to anomaly.
n

analysand
a person undergoing psychoanalysis.
n

analyse
Same as Analyze Analyzer etc.
misc

analyser
an instrument that performs analyses.
n

analysis
A resolution of anything whether an object of the senses or of the intellect into its constituent or original elements; an examination of the component parts of a subject each separately as the words which compose a sentence the tones of a tune or the simple propositions which enter into an argument. It is opposed to synthesis;  The separation of a compound substance by chemical processes into its constituents with a view to ascertain either (a) what elements it contains or (b) how much of each element is present. The former is called qualitative and the latter quantitative analysis;  The tracing of things to their source and the resolving of knowledge into its original principles;  The resolving of problems by reducing the conditions that are in them to equations;  A syllabus or table of the principal heads of a discourse disposed in their natural order;  The process of ascertaining the name of a species or its place in a system of classification by means of an analytical table or key.
n

analysis-of-variance
a statistical technique by which the results of an observation or experiment are analyzed to determine the relative contributions of the different possible causative factors or variables to the outcome. Abbreviated ANOVA.
n

analyst
One who analyzes; formerly one skilled in algebraical geometry; now commonly one skilled in chemical analysis.
n

analytic
Of or pertaining to analysis; resolving into elements or constituent parts; as an analytical experiment; -- opposed to synthetic.
adj

analytical
of or pertaining to analysis (definition 2);  of a proposition; necessarily true independent of fact or experience such as “all spinsters are unmarried”. Opposite of synthetic;  exercising or involving careful analytical evaluations; as analytic reasoning; an analytical discussion;  capable of or given to analyzing; -- of people.
adj

analytically
In an analytical manner.
adv

analytics
The science of analysis.
n

analyzable
That may be analyzed.
adj

analyzation
The act of analyzing or separating into constituent parts; analysis.
n

analyze
To subject to analysis; to resolve (anything complex) into its elements; to separate into the constituent parts for the purpose of an examination of each separately; to examine in such a manner as to ascertain the elements or nature of the thing examined; to consider in detail in order to discover essential features or meaning; as to analyze an action to ascertain its morality; to analyse a sonnet by Shakespeare; to analyse the evidence in a criminal trial; to analyse your real motives;  make a mathematical chemical or grammatical analysis of; break down into components or essential features; as to analyse a specimen; to analyze a fossil substance; to analyze a sentence or a word; to analyse a chemical compound;  subject to psychoanalytic treatment.
v

analyzed
separated into components.
adj

analyzer
One who or that which analyzes;  The part of a polariscope which receives the light after polarization and exhibits its properties.

anapest
A metrical foot consisting of three syllables the first two short or unaccented the last long or accented (˘ ˘ -); the reverse of the dactyl. In Latin dĕ-ĭ-tās and in English in-ter-vene" are examples of anapests;  A verse composed of such feet.

adj

anaphor
a word (such as a pronoun) used to avoid repetition; the referent of an anaphor is determined by its antecedent.
n

anaphora
A repetition of a word or of words at the beginning of two or more successive clauses;  the use of a substitute word such as a pronoun in reference to a something already mentioned in a discourse; also the relation between the substitute word and its antecedent. It is contrasted with cataphora the use of a pronoun for a word or topic not yet mentioned.
n

anaphoric

adj

anaphrodisia

n

anaphrodisiac
Same as Antaphrodisiac.
adj

anaphroditic

adj

anaphylactic
of or pertaining to anaphylaxis; caused by anaphylaxis.
n

anaphylactic-shock
a severe form of physiological shock often having a fatal outcome caused by an extreme immunological reaction to antigens. It is a severe form of anaphylaxis{2} and is characterized by smooth muscle contraction and capillary dilation throughout the body initiated by antibodies of the IgE class. It is usually seen when an antigen to which a person has become hypersensitized is injected intravenously or subcutaneously. It is also called generalyzed anaphylaxis or systemic anaphylaxis and sometimes anaphylaxis.
n

anaphylaxis
hypersensitivity (to a protein or drug) resulting from prior contact with a substance;  an immediate but transient allergic reaction to an antigenic substance to which a person has become hypersensitized; it is characterized by the contraction of smooth muscle and capillary dilation. These reactions are caused by the release of certain substances such as histamine bradykinin serotonin and slow-reacting substance in response to the reaction of the antigen with a mast cell-fixed antibody chiefly IgE. This term is sometimes used to refer to the severe form of the reaction called anaphylactic shock.
n

anaplasia
loss of structural differentiation within a cell or group of cells often with increased capacity for multiplication as in a malignant tumor.
n

anaplastic
Of or pertaining to anaplasty.
adj

anaplasty
The art of operation of restoring lost parts or the normal shape by the use of healthy tissue.
n

anaplerotic
Filling up; promoting granulation of wounds or ulcers.
adj

anapnograph
A form of spirometer.
n

anapnoic
Relating to respiration.
adj

anapodeictic
Not apodeictic; undemonstrable.
adj

anapophysis

n

n

anatomy
The art of dissecting or artificially separating the different parts of any organized body to discover their situation structure and economy; dissection;  The science which treats of the structure of organic bodies; anatomical structure or organization;  A treatise or book on anatomy;  The act of dividing anything corporeal or intellectual for the purpose of examining its parts; analysis; as the anatomy of a discourse;  A skeleton; anything anatomized or dissected or which has the appearance of being so.
n

anatreptic
Overthrowing; defeating; -- applied to Plato's refutative dialogues.
adj

anatron
Native carbonate of soda; natron;  Glass gall or sandiver;  Saltpeter.
n

anatropal
Having the ovule inverted at an early period in its development so that the chalaza is as the apparent apex; -- opposed to orthotropous.
adj

anatto
Same as Annotto.
n

anbury
A soft tumor or bloody wart on horses or oxen;  A disease of the roots of turnips etc;  -- called also fingers and toes.
n

-ance
A suffix signifying action; also quality or state; as assistance resistance appearance elegance. See -ancy.
misc

ancestor
One from whom a person is descended whether on the father's or mother's side at any distance of time; a progenitor; a fore father;  An earlier type; a progenitor; as this fossil animal is regarded as the ancestor of the horse;  One from whom an estate has descended; -- the correlative of heir.
n

ancestorial
Ancestral.
adj

ancestorially
With regard to ancestors.
adv

ancestral
Of pertaining to derived from or possessed by an ancestor or ancestors; as an ancestral estate.
adj

ancestress
A female ancestor.
n

ancestry
Condition as to ancestors; ancestral lineage; hence birth or honorable descent;  A series of ancestors or progenitors; lineage or those who compose the line of natural descent.
n

anchor
A iron instrument which is attached to a ship by a cable (rope or chain) and which being cast overboard lays hold of the earth by a fluke or hook and thus retains the ship in a particular station;  Any instrument or contrivance serving a purpose like that of a ship's anchor as an arrangement of timber to hold a dam fast; a contrivance to hold the end of a bridge cable or other similar part; a contrivance used by founders to hold the core of a mold in place;  Fig.: That which gives stability or security; that on which we place dependence for safety;  An emblem of hope;  A metal tie holding adjoining parts of a building together;  One of the anchor-shaped spicules of certain sponges; also one of the calcareous spinules of certain Holothurians as in species of Synapta;  an achorman anchorwoman or anchorperson;  To place at anchor; to secure by an anchor; as to anchor a ship; To fix or fasten; to fix in a stable condition; as to anchor the cables of a suspension bridge;  To cast anchor; to come to anchor; as our ship (or the captain) anchored in the stream; To stop; to fix or rest;  An anchoret.
n

anchorable
Fit for anchorage.
adj

anchorage
The act of anchoring or the condition of lying at anchor;  A place suitable for anchoring or where ships anchor; a hold for an anchor;  The set of anchors belonging to a ship;  Something which holds like an anchor; a hold; as the anchorages of the Brooklyn Bridge;  Something on which one may depend for security; ground of trust;  A toll for anchoring; anchorage duties;  Abode of an anchoret.
n

anchorate
Anchor-shaped.
adj

anchored
Held by an anchor; at anchor; held safely; as an anchored bark; also shaped like an anchor; forked; as an anchored tongue;  Having the extremities turned back like the flukes of an anchor; as an anchored cross.
adj

anchor-escapement
The common recoil escapement.
misc

anchoress
A female anchoret.
n

anchoret
One who renounces the world and secludes himself usually for religious reasons; a hermit; a recluse.
n

anchoretic
Pertaining to an anchoret or hermit; after the manner of an anchoret.
adj

anchoretish
Hermitlike.
adj

anchoretism
The practice or mode of life of an anchoret.
n

anchor-hold
The hold or grip of an anchor or that to which it holds;  Hence: Firm hold: security.
n

anchorite
Same as Anchoret.
n

anchoritess
An anchoress.
n

anchorless
Without an anchor or stay. Hence: Drifting; unsettled.
adj

anchor-light
The lantern shown at night by a vessel at anchor. International rules of the road require vessels at anchor to carry from sunset to sunrise a single white light forward if under 150 feet in length and if longer two such lights one near the stern and one forward.
misc

anchorman
a woman television reporter who coordinates a broadcast to which several correspondents contribute. Male correlate of anchorwoman.
n

anchorperson
an anchorman or anchorwoman.. The anchorperson usually begins the broadcast discusses certain topics and introduces new topics which may be discussed by other reprorters especially when the report is recorded or broadcast from a location other than the main broadcast studio.
n

anchor-shot
A shot made with the object balls in an anchor space.
misc

anchor-space
In the balk-line game any of eight spaces 7 inches by 312 lying along a cushion and bisected transversely by a balk line. Object balls in an anchor space are treated as in balk.
misc

anchor-watch
A detail of one or more men who keep watch on deck at night when a vessel is at anchor.
misc

anchorwoman
a woman television reporter who coordinates a broadcast to which several correspondents contribute. Female correlate of anchorman.
n

anchovy
A small fish about three inches in length of the Herring family (Engraulis encrasicholus) caught in vast numbers in the Mediterranean and pickled for exportation. The name is also applied to several allied species.
n

anchovy-pear
A West Indian fruit like the mango in taste sometimes pickled; also the tree (Grias cauliflora) bearing this fruit.
misc

anchusa
any of various Old World herbs of the genus Anchusa having one-sided clusters of trumpet-shaped flowers.
n

anchusin
A resinoid coloring matter obtained from alkanet root.
n

anchylose
To affect or be affected with anchylosis; to unite or consolidate so as to make a stiff joint; to grow together into one.
v

anchylosis
Stiffness or fixation of a joint; formation of a stiff joint;  The union of two or more separate bones to from a single bone; the close union of bones or other structures in various animals;  abnormal adhesion and rigidity of the bones of a joint.
n

anchylotic
Of or pertaining to anchylosis.
adj

ancient
Old; that happened or existed in former times usually at a great distance of time; belonging to times long past; specifically applied to the times before the fall of the Roman empire; -- opposed to modern; as ancient authors literature history; ancient days;  Old; that has been of long duration; of long standing; of great age; as an ancient forest; an ancient castle;  Known for a long time or from early times; -- opposed to recent or new; as the ancient continent;  Dignified like an aged man; magisterial; venerable;  Experienced; versed;  Former; sometime;  Those who lived in former ages as opposed to the moderns; An aged man; a patriarch. Hence: A governor; a ruler; a person of influence; A senior; an elder; a predecessor; One of the senior members of the Inns of Court or of Chancery;  An ensign or flag; The bearer of a flag; an ensign.
adj

anciently
In ancient times;  In an ancient manner.
adv

ancientness
The quality of being ancient; antiquity; existence from old times.
n

ancientry
Antiquity; what is ancient;  Old age; also old people;  Ancient lineage; ancestry; dignity of birth.
n

ancienty
Age; antiquity;  Seniority.
n

ancile
The sacred shield of the Romans said to have-fallen from heaven in the reign of Numa. It was the palladium of Rome.
n

ancillary
Subservient or subordinate like a handmaid; auxiliary.
adj

ancillary-administration
An administration subordinate to and in aid of the primary or principal administration of an estate.
misc

ancille
A maidservant; a handmaid.
n

ancipital
Two-edged instead of round; -- said of certain flattened stems as those of blue grass and rarely also of leaves.
adj

ancistroid
Hook-shaped.
adj

ancle
See Ankle.
n

ancome
A small ulcerous swelling coming suddenly; also a whitlow.
n

ancon
The olecranon or the elbow;  The corner or quoin of a wall cross-beam or rafter.
n

anconal
Of or pertaining to the ancon or elbow.
adj

anconeus
A muscle of the elbow and forearm.
n

anconoid
Elbowlike; anconal.
adj

ancony
A piece of malleable iron wrought into the shape of a bar in the middle but unwrought at the ends.
n

-ancy
A suffix expressing more strongly than -ance the idea of quality or state; as constancy buoyancy infancy.
misc

and
A particle which expresses the relation of connection or addition. It is used to conjoin a word with a word a clause with a clause or a sentence with a sentence;  In order to; -- used instead of the infinitival to especially after try come go;  It is sometimes in old songs a mere expletive;  If; though. See An conj.
misc

andabatism
Doubt; uncertainty.
n

andalusite
A silicate of aluminium occurring usually in thick rhombic prisms nearly square of a grayish or pale reddish tint. It was first discovered in Andalusia Spain.
n

andante
Moving moderately slow but distinct and flowing; quicker than larghetto and slower than allegretto.
adj

andantino
Rather quicker than andante; between that allegretto.
adj

andarac
Red orpiment.
n

andean
Pertaining to the Andes.
adj

andesine
A kind of triclinic feldspar found in the Andes.
n

andesite
An eruptive rock allied to trachyte consisting essentially of a triclinic feldspar with pyroxene hornblende or hypersthene.
n

andine
Andean; as Andine flora.
adj

andira
small genus of evergreen trees of tropical America and West Africa.
n

andiron
A utensil for supporting wood when burning in a fireplace one being placed on each side; a firedog; as a pair of andirons.
n

andosite
dark grayish extrusive rock.
n

andranatomy
The dissection of a human body especially of a male; androtomy.
n

andreaea
a genus of brown or blackish Alpine mosses having a dehiscent capsule with 4 longitudinal slits.
n

andreaeales
an order of mosses which comprises a single genus: Andreaea.
n

andrena
a bee that is a a member of the genus Andrena..
n

andrenid
a bee that is a a member of the genus Andrena..
n

andrenidae
a large family of solitary short-tongued bees most of which burrow in the ground.
n

andrew
one of the twelve apostles of Jesus; brother of Peter; patron saint of Scotland.
n

andricus
a genus of cynipid gall wasps chiefly affecting oaks.
n

androcephalous
Having a human head (upon an animal's body) as the Egyptian sphinx.
adj

androdioecious
Having perfect and staminate flowers on different plants.
adj

androecium
The stamens of a flower taken collectively.
n

androgen
a hormone such as testosterone or androsterone that promotes development and maintenance of typical male sexual characteristics. They are mostly produced in the testes.
n

androgenic
of or pertaining to androgens; having physiological effects like that of an androgen.
adj

androgyne
An hermaphrodite;  An androgynous plant.
n

androgynous
Uniting both sexes in one or having the characteristics of both; being in nature both male and female; hermaphroditic;  Bearing both staminiferous and pistilliferous flowers in the same cluster.
adj

androgyny
Union of both sexes in one individual; hermaphroditism.
n

android
A machine or automaton in the form of a human being;  Resembling a man.
n

andromeda
A northern constellation supposed to represent the mythical Andromeda;  A genus of ericaceous flowering plants of northern climates of which the original species was found growing on a rock surrounded by water.
n

andromede
A meteor appearing to radiate from a point in the constellation Andromeda -- whence the name.
n

andron
The apartment appropriated for the males. This was in the lower part of the house.
n

andropetalous
Produced by the conversion of the stamens into petals as double flowers like the garden ranunculus.
adj

androphagi
Cannibals; man-eaters; anthropophagi.
n

androphagous
Anthropophagous.
adj

androphore
A support or column on which stamens are raised;  The part which in some Siphonophora bears the male gonophores.
n

andropogon
A very large and important genus of grasses found in nearly all parts of the world. It includes the lemon grass of Ceylon and the beard grass or broom sedge of the United States. The principal subgenus is Sorghum including Andropogon sorghum and Andropogon halepensis from which have been derived the Chinese sugar cane the Johnson grass the Aleppo grass the broom corn and the durra or Indian millet. Several East Indian species as Andropogon nardus and Andropogon schoenanthus yield fragrant oils used in perfumery.
n

androsphinx
A man sphinx; a sphinx having the head of a man and the body of a lion.
n

androspore
A spore of some algae which has male functions.
n

androtomous
Having the filaments of the stamens divided into two parts.
adj

androtomy
Dissection of the human body as distinguished from zootomy; anthropotomy.
n

androus
A terminal combining form: Having a stamen or stamens; staminate; as monandrous with one stamen; polyandrous with many stamens.

anear
Near;  To near; to approach.

adj

anemometrograph
An anemograph.
n

anemometry
The act or process of ascertaining the force or velocity of the wind.
n

anemone
A genus of plants of the Ranunculus or Crowfoot family; windflower. Some of the species are cultivated in gardens;  The sea anemone. See Actinia and Sea anemone.
n

anemonella
a genus consisting of one species: the rue anemone.
n

anemonic
An acrid poisonous crystallizable substance obtained from the anemone or from anemonin.
adj

anemonin
An acrid poisonous crystallizable substance obtained from some species of anemone.
n

anemony
See Anemone.
n

anemophilous
pollinated by the wind; -- of flowering plants; especially grasses etc.
adj

anemopsis
a genus consisting of one species: the yerba mansa.
n

anemorphilous
Fertilized by the agency of the wind; -- said of plants in which the pollen is carried to the stigma by the wind; wind-Fertilized.
adj

anemoscope
An instrument which shows the direction of the wind; a wind vane; a weathercock; -- usually applied to a contrivance consisting of a vane above connected in the building with a dial or index with pointers to show the changes of the wind.
n

anemosis
A condition in the wood of some trees in which the rings are separated as some suppose by the action of high winds upon the trunk; wind shake.
n

anencephalic
Without a brain; brainless.
adj

anenst
Over against; as he lives anent the church;  About; concerning; in respect; as he said nothing anent this particular.
prep

anenterous

Containing no liquid; -- said of a kind of barometer;  An aneroid barometer.

anes
Once.

v

anesthetized
rendered insensible by anesthetizing. Same as anaesthetized.
adj

anesthyl
a mixture of methyl chloride and ethyl chloride; sprayed on as a local anesthetic.
n

anestrous
of or pertaining to anestrus;  not in a state of estrus; not in heat; -- of lower mammals; as an anestrous bitch. Opposite of estrous.
adj

anestrus
a state or interval of sexual inactivity between two periods of estrus; -- applies to nonhuman mammals.
n

anet
The herb dill or dillseed.
n

anethol
A substance obtained from the volatile oils of anise fennel etc. in the form of soft shining scales; -- called also anise camphor.
n

anethum
a genus of plants of the parsley family having aromatic seeds and finely divided leaves including the dill Anethum graveolens.
n

anetic
Soothing.
adj

aneurin
same as thiamin; a B vitamin (vitamin B1) that prevents beriberi.
n

aneurism
A soft pulsating hollow tumor containing blood arising from the preternatural dilation or rupture of the coats of an artery.
n

aneurismal
Of or pertaining to an aneurism; as an aneurismal tumor; aneurismal diathesis.
adj

aneurismatic
of or pertaining to an aneurysm.
adj

aneurysm
a sac-like widening of a blood vessel.
n

anew
Over again; another time; in a new form; afresh; as to arm anew; to create anew.
adv

anfractuose
Anfractuous; as anfractuose anthers.

A state of being anfractuous or full of windings and turnings; sinuosity;  A sinuous depression or sulcus like those separating the convolutions of the brain.
n

anfractuous
Winding; full of windings and turnings; sinuous; tortuous; as the anfractuous spires of a born.
adj

anfracture
A mazy winding.
n

angariation
Exaction of forced service; compulsion.
n

angeiology
Same as Angiology Angiotomy etc.
misc

angel
A messenger;  A spiritual celestial being superior to man in power and intelligence. In the Scriptures the angels appear as God's messengers;  One of a class of “fallen angels;” an evil spirit; as the devil and his angels;  A minister or pastor of a church as in the Seven Asiatic churches;  Attendant spirit; genius; demon;  An appellation given to a person supposed to be of angelic goodness or loveliness; a darling;  An ancient gold coin of England bearing the figure of the archangel Michael. It varied in value from 6s. 8d. to 10s.
n

angelage
Existence or state of angels.
n

angelet
A small gold coin formerly current in England; a half angel.
n

angel-fish
See under Angel.
misc

angelhood
The state of being an angel; angelic nature.
n

angelic
Belonging to or proceeding from angels; resembling characteristic of or partaking of the nature of an angel; heavenly; divine;  having a sweet nature befitting an angel or cherub; as an angelic smile;  marked by utter benignity; resembling or befitting an angel or saint; as angelic benificence;  Of or derived from angelica; as angelic acid; angelic ether.
adj

angelica
An aromatic umbelliferous plant (Archangelica officinalis or Angelica archangelica) the leaf stalks of which are sometimes candied and used in confectionery and the roots and seeds as an aromatic tonic;  The candied leaf stalks of angelica.
n

angelically
Like an angel.
adv

angelicalness
The quality of being angelic; excellence more than human.
n

angelify
To make like an angel; to angelize.
v

angelize
To raise to the state of an angel; to render angelic.
v

angellike
Resembling an angel.
adj

angelolatry
Worship paid to angels.
n

angelology
A discourse on angels or a body of doctrines in regard to angels.
n

angelophany
The actual appearance of an angel to man.
n

angelot
A French gold coin of the reign of Louis XI. bearing the image of St. Michael; also a piece coined at Paris by the English under Henry VI;  An instrument of music of the lute kind now disused;  A sort of small rich cheese made in Normandy.
n

angelus
A form of devotion in which three Ave Marias are repeated. It is said at morning noon and evening at the sound of a bell.
n

anger
Trouble; vexation; also physical pain or smart of a sore etc;  A strong passion or emotion of displeasure or antagonism excited by a real or supposed injury or insult to one's self or others or by the intent to do such injury;  To make painful; to cause to smart; to inflame; To excite to anger; to enrage; to provoke.
n

angerly
Angrily.
adv

angevin
a resident of Anjou.
n

angevine
Of or pertaining to Anjou in France.
adj

angienchyma
Vascular tissue of plants consisting of spiral vessels dotted barred and pitted ducts and laticiferous vessels.
n

angina
Any inflammatory affection of the throat or faces as the quinsy malignant sore throat croup etc. especially such as tends to produce suffocation choking or shortness of breath.
n

anginal
of or pertaining to angina or angina pectoris.
adj

anginous
Pertaining to angina or angina pectoris.
adj

angio-
A prefix or combining form in numerous compounds usually relating to seed or blood vessels or to something contained in or covered by a vessel.
misc

angiocarp
tree bearing fruit enclosed in a shell or involucre or husk.
n

angiocarpic
of or pertaining to an angiocarp; angiocarpous.
adj

angiocarpous
Having fruit inclosed within a covering that does not form a part of itself; as the filbert covered by its husk or the acorn seated in its cupule.
adj

angiogram
am X-ray photograph produced by angiography.
n

angiography
A description of blood vessels and lymphatics;  a diagnostic procedure in which the location and size of blood vessels may be visualized by taking an X-ray photograph after injecting a radiopaque substance into the blood stream.
n

angiology
That part of anatomy which treats of blood vessels and lymphatics.
n

angioma
A tumor composed chiefly of dilated blood or lymph vessels.
n

angiomonospermous
Producing one seed only in a seed pod.
adj

angioneurosis
Any disorder of the vasomotor system; neurosis of a blood vessel.
n

angiopathy
Disease of the vessels esp. the blood vessels.
n

angiopteris
a highly variable species (Angiopteris evecta) of very large primitive ferns of the Pacific tropical areas with high rainfall.
n

angioscope
An instrument for examining the capillary vessels of animals and plants.
n

angiosperm
A plant which has its seeds inclosed in a pericarp. Contrasted with gymnosperm.
n

angiospermatous
Same as Angiospermous.
adj

angiospermous
Having seeds inclosed in a pod or other pericarp.
adj

angiosporous
Having spores contained in cells or thecae as in the case of some fungi.
adj

angiostomous
With a narrow mouth as the shell of certain gastropods.
adj

angiotomy
Dissection of the blood vessels and lymphatics of the body.
n

angle
The inclosed space near the point where two lines meet; a corner; a nook;  The figure made by. two lines which meet;  A projecting or sharp corner; an angular fragment;  A name given to four of the twelve astrological “houses.”;  A fishhook; tackle for catching fish consisting of a line hook and bait with or without a rod;  To fish with an angle (fishhook) or with hook and line; To use some bait or artifice; to intrigue; to scheme; as to angle for praise;  To try to gain by some insinuating artifice; to allure.
n

angled
Having an angle or angles; -- used in compounds; as right-angled many-angled etc.
adj

angledozer
a bulldozer with an angled moldboard to push earth to one side.
n

anglemeter
An instrument to measure angles esp. one used by geologists to measure the dip of strata.
n

angle-of-entry
The angle between the tangent to the advancing edge (of an aerocurve) and the line of motion; -- contrasted with angle of trail which is the angle between the tangent to the following edge and the line of motion.
misc

angle-of-incidence
The angle between the chord of an aerocurve and the relative direction of the undisturbed air current.
misc

angle-park
to park (a road vehicle) at an angle to the curb; -- contrasted with parallel-park.
v

angler
One who angles;  A fish (Lophius piscatorius) of Europe and America having a large broad and depressed head with the mouth very large. Peculiar appendages on the head are said to be used to entice fishes within reach. Called also fishing frog frogfish toadfish goosefish allmouth monkfish etc.
n

angles
An ancient Low German tribe that settled in Britain which came to be called Engla-land (Angleland or England). The Angles probably came from the district of Angeln (now within the limits of Schleswig) and the country now Lower Hanover etc.
n

anglesite
A native sulphate of lead. It occurs in white or yellowish transparent prismatic crystals.
n

anglewise
In an angular manner; angularly.
adv

angleworm
A earthworm of the genus Lumbricus frequently used by anglers for bait. See Earthworm.
n

anglian
Of or pertaining to the Angles.
adj

anglic
Anglian.
adj

anglican
English; of or pertaining to England or the English nation; especially pertaining to or connected with the established church of England; as the Anglican church doctrine orders ritual etc;  Pertaining to characteristic of or held by the high church party of the Church of England;  A member of the Church of England; In a restricted sense a member of the High Church party or of the more advanced ritualistic section in the Church of England.
adj

anglicanism
Strong partiality to the principles and rites of the Church of England;  The principles of the established church of England; also in a restricted sense the doctrines held by the high-church party;  Attachment to England or English institutions.
n

anglice
In English; in the English manner; as Livorno Anglice Leghorn.
adv

anglicify
To anglicize.
v

anglicism
An English idiom; a phrase or form language peculiar to the English;  The quality of being English; an English characteristic custom or method.
n

anglicity
The state or quality of being English.
n

anglicization
The act of anglicizing or making English in character.
n

anglicize
To make English; to English; to anglify; render conformable to the English idiom or to English analogies.
v

anglify
To convert into English; to anglicize.
v

angling
The act of one who angles; the art of fishing with rod and line.
n

anglo-
A combining form meaning the same as English; or English and or English conjoined with; as Anglo-Turkish treaty Anglo-German Anglo-Irish.
misc

anglo-american
Of or pertaining to the English and Americans or to the descendants of Englishmen in America;  an American who was born in England or whose ancestors were English.
adj

anglo-catholic
Of or pertaining to a church modeled on the English Reformation; Anglican; -- sometimes restricted to the ritualistic or High Church section of the Church of England;  A member of the Church of England who contends for its catholic character; more specifically a High Churchman.
adj

anglo-catholicism
The belief of those in the Church of England who accept many doctrines and practices which they maintain were those of the primitive or true Catholic Church of which they consider the Church of England to be the lineal descendant; a doctrine and practice within the Church of England emphasizing the Catholic tradition.
n

anglo-french
the French (Norman) language used in medieval England.
n

anglo-indian
relating to British India or the English in India or to the English and East Indian peoples or languages;  a person of English citizenship born or living in India; One of the Anglo-Indian race born or resident in the East Indies.
adj

anglo-jewish
of English-speaking jews and their culture.
adj

anglomania
A mania for or an inordinate attachment to English customs institutions etc.
n

anglomaniac
One affected with Anglomania.
n

anglo-norman
Of or pertaining to the English and Normans or to the Normans who settled in England;  One of the English Normans or the Normans who conquered England; the French (Norman) language used in medieval England.
adj

anglophile
an admirer of England and things English.
n

anglophilia
exaggerated admiration for England and English customs.
n

anglophilic
of or pertaining to Anglophilia.
adj

anglophobe
a person who hates England and everything English.
n

anglophobia
Intense dread of or aversion to England or the English.
n

anglo-saxon
of or pertaining to the Anglo-Saxons or their language; as Anglo-Saxon poetry; The Anglo-Saxon population of Scotland;  A Saxon of Britain that is an English Saxon or one the Saxons who settled in England as distinguished from a continental (or “Old”) Saxon; The Teutonic people (Angles Saxons Jutes) of England or the English people collectively before the Norman Conquest; The language of the English people before the Norman conquest in 1066 (sometimes called Old English). See Saxon; One of the race or people who claim descent from the Saxons Angles or other Teutonic tribes who settled in England; a person of English descent in its broadest sense; a person of Anglo-Saxon (esp British) descent whose native tongue is English and whose culture is strongly influenced by English culture as in "WASP for `White Anglo-Saxon Protestant'"; "this Anglo-Saxon view of things".
adj

anglo-saxondom
The Anglo-Saxon domain (i. e. Great Britain and the United States etc.); the Anglo-Saxon race.
n

anglo-saxonism
A characteristic of the Anglo-Saxon race; especially a word or an idiom of the Anglo-Saxon tongue;  The quality or sentiment of being Anglo-Saxon or English in its ethnological sense.
n

angola
A fabric made from the wool of the Angora goat.
n

angola-pea
A tropical plant (Cajanus indicus) and its edible seed a kind of pulse; -- so called from Angola in Western Africa. Called also pigeon pea and Congo pea.
misc

angolese
a member of the Bantu tribes resident in Angola.
n

angor
Great anxiety accompanied by painful constriction at the upper part of the belly often with palpitation and oppression.
n

angora
A city of Asia Minor (or Anatolia) which has given its name to a goat a cat etc.
n

angostura
A bitter aromatic bark obtained from a South American tree of the rue family (Galipea cusparia or Galipea officinalis). It is used used as a tonic in medicines liqueurs and bitters.
misc

angoumois-moth
A small moth (Gelechia cerealella) which is very destructive to wheat and other grain. The larva eats out the interior of the grain leaving only the shell.
misc

angraecum
a genus of tropical Old World epiphytic orchids with showy flowers sometimes grotesque.
n

angrecum
any of various spectacular orchids of the genus Angraecum having 2-ranked dark green leathery leaves and usually nocturnally scented white or ivory flowers.
n

n

anhydrite
A mineral of a white or a slightly bluish color usually massive. It is anhydrous sulphate of lime and differs from gypsum in not containing water (whence the name).

n

adj

anilide
One of a class of compounds which may be regarded as amides in which more or less of the hydrogen has been replaced by phenyl.
n

aniline
An organic base belonging to the phenylamines. It may be regarded as ammonia in which one hydrogen atom has been replaced by the radical phenyl. It is a colorless oily liquid originally obtained from indigo by distillation but now largely manufactured from coal tar or nitrobenzene as a base from which many brilliant dyes are made;  Made from or of the nature of aniline.
n

anilinism
A disease due to inhaling the poisonous fumes present in the manufacture of aniline.
n

anility
The state of being and old woman; old-womanishness; dotage.
n

n

animal
An organized living being endowed with sensation and the power of voluntary motion and also characterized by taking its food into an internal cavity or stomach for digestion; by giving carbonic acid to the air and taking oxygen in the process of respiration; and by increasing in motive power or active aggressive force with progress to maturity;  One of the lower animals; a brute or beast as distinguished from man; as men and animals;  Of or relating to animals; as animal functions; Pertaining to the merely sentient part of a creature as distinguished from the intellectual rational or spiritual part; as the animal passions or appetites; Consisting of the flesh of animals; as animal food.

n

ankylostomiasis
A disease due to the presence of the parasites Agchylostoma duodenale Uncinaria (subgenus Necator) americana or allied nematodes in the small intestine. When present in large numbers they produce a severe anaemia by sucking the blood from the intestinal walls. Called also miner's anaemia tunnel disease brickmaker's anaemia Egyptian chlorosis.

A broad dagger formerly worn at the girdle.

annelid

adj

annelida
A division of the Articulata having the body formed of numerous rings or annular segments and without jointed legs. The principal subdivisions are the Chaetopoda including the Oligochaeta or earthworms and Polychaeta or marine worms; and the Hirudinea or leeches. See Chaetopoda.
n

annelidous
Of the nature of an annelid.
adj

annellata
See Annelida.
n

v

The act of annexing; process of attaching adding or appending; the act of connecting; union; as the annexation of Texas to the United States or of chattels to the freehold;  The union of property with a freehold so as to become a fixture. adj

annuloida
A division of the Articulata including the annelids and allied groups; sometimes made to include also the helminths and echinoderms.
n

annulosa
A division of the Invertebrata nearly equivalent to the Articulata. It includes the Arthoropoda and Anarthropoda. By some zoologists it is applied to the former only.

n

annulose
Furnished with or composed of rings or ringlike segments; ringed;  Of or pertaining to the Annulosa.
adj

A ring; a ringlike part or space;  A space contained between the circumferences of two circles one within the other;  Ring-shaped structures or markings found in or upon various animals.
n

annumerate
To add on; to count in.
v

annumeration
Addition to a former number.
n

That may be announced or declared; declarable.
adj

annunciate
To announce;  Foretold; preannounced.
v

annunciation
The act of announcing; announcement; proclamation; as the annunciation of peace;  The announcement of the incarnation made by the angel Gabriel to the Virgin Mary.
n

annunciation-lily
The common white lily (Lilium candidum). So called because it is usually introduced by painters in pictures of the Annunciation.
misc

annunciative
Pertaining to annunciation; announcing.
adj

annunciator
One who announces. Specifically: An officer in the church of Constantinople whose business it was to inform the people of the festivals to be celebrated;  An indicator (as in a hotel) which designates the room where attendance is wanted.
n

annunciatory
Pertaining to or containing announcement; making known.
adj

annwfn
the other world; land of fairies.
n

the other world; land of fairies.
n

anoa
A small wild ox of Celebes (Anoa depressicornis) allied to the buffalo but having long nearly straight horns.
n

anobiidae
the family comprising the deathwatch beetles.
n

anodal
of or at or relating to an anode. Contrastive to cathodic.
adj

anode
The positive pole of an electric battery or more strictly the electrode by which the current enters the electrolyte on its way to the other pole; -- opposed to cathode.
n

anodize
to coat a metal with an oxide coat by electrolytic action at an anode; -- used especially to coat aluminum.
v

anodon
A genus of fresh-water bivalves having no teeth at the hinge.
n

anodonta
a genus of thin-shelled freshwater mussels.
n

adj

adj

anoetic
Unthinkable;  Not subject to conscious attention; having an indefinite relatively passive conscious being; characteristic of the “fringe” or “margin” of consciousness.
adj

anoil

v

To smear or rub over with oil or an unctuous substance; also to spread over as oil;  To apply oil to or to pour oil upon etc. as a sacred rite especially for consecration;  Anointed.
v

anointer
One who anoints.
n

anointment
The act of anointing or state of being anointed; also an ointment.
n

anole
A small arboreal tropical American insectivorous lizard (Anolis carolinensis) with the ability to change skin color.
n

anolis
A genus of lizards which belong to the family Iguanidae. They take the place in the New World of the chameleons in the Old and in America are often called chameleons.
pn

anomal
Anything anomalous.
n

anomaliped
Having anomalous feet;  One of a group of perching birds having the middle toe more or less united to the outer and inner ones.
adj

anomalism

n

anomalistic
Irregular; departing from common or established rules;  Pertaining to the anomaly or angular distance of a planet from its perihelion.
adj

With irregularity.
adv

anomaloflorous
Having anomalous flowers.
adj

anomalopidae
a natural family comprising the flashlightfishes.
n

anomalops
a fish having a luminous organ beneath eye; it inhabits warm waters of the West Pacific and Puerto Rico. It is called also flashlight fish.
n

anomalopteryx
the smallest moa (Anomalopteryx oweni); it is a slender moa about the size of a large turkey.
n

anomalous
Deviating from a general rule method or analogy; abnormal; irregular; as an anomalous proceeding.
adj

anomalously
In an anomalous manner.
adv

anomalousness
Quality of being anomalous.
n

anomaly
Deviation from the common rule; an irregularity; anything anomalous;  The angular distance of a planet from its perihelion as seen from the sun. This is the true anomaly. The eccentric anomaly is a corresponding angle at the center of the elliptic orbit of the planet. The mean anomaly is what the anomaly would be if the planet's angular motion were uniform;  Any deviation from the essential characteristics of a specific type.
n

anomia
A genus of bivalve shells allied to the oyster so called from their unequal valves of which the lower is perforated for attachment.
n

anomophyllous
Having leaves irregularly placed.
adj

anomura
A group of decapod Crustacea of which the hermit crab in an example.
n

anomural
Irregular in the character of the tail or abdomen; as the anomural crustaceans.
adj

anomuran
One of the Anomura.
n

anomy
Disregard or violation of law.
n

anon
Straightway; at once;  Soon; in a little while;  At another time; then; again.
adv

anona
A genus of tropical or subtropical plants of the natural order Anonaceae including the soursop.
n

anonaceous
Pertaining to the order of plants including the soursop custard apple etc.
adj

anonym
One who is anonymous; also sometimes used for “pseudonym.”;  A notion which has no name or which can not be expressed by a single English word.
n

anonymity
The quality or state of being anonymous; anonymousness; also that which anonymous.
n

anonymous
Nameless; of unknown name; also of unknown or unavowed authorship; as an anonymous benefactor; an anonymous pamphlet or letter.
adj

anonymously
In an anonymous manner; without a name.
adv

anonymousness
The state or quality of being anonymous.
n

anopheles
A genus of mosquitoes which are secondary hosts of the malaria parasites and whose bite is the usual if not the only means of infecting human beings with malaria. Several species are found in the United States. They may be distinguished from the ordinary mosquitoes of the genus Culex by the long slender palpi nearly equaling the beak in length while those of the female Culex are very short. They also assume different positions when resting Culex usually holding the body parallel to the surface on which it rests and keeping the head and beak bent at an angle while Anopheles holds the body at an angle with the surface and the head and beak in line with it. Unless they become themselves infected by previously biting a subject affected with malaria the insects cannot transmit the disease.
n

anophyte
A moss or mosslike plant which cellular stems having usually an upward growth and distinct leaves.
n

anopla
One of the two orders of Nemerteans. See Nemertina.
n

anoplothere
A genus of extinct quadrupeds of the order Ungulata whose were first found in the gypsum quarries near Paris; characterized by the shortness and feebleness of their canine teeth (whence the name).
n

anoplura
A group of insects which includes the lice.
n

anopsia
Want or defect of sight; blindness.
adj

anorexia
Want of appetite without a loathing of food.
n

anorexigenic
causing loss of appetite; as an anorectic (or anorexigenic) drug.
adj

anormal
Not according to rule; abnormal.
adj

anorn
To adorn.
v

anorthic
Having unequal oblique axes; as anorthic crystals.
adj

anorthite
A mineral of the feldspar family commonly occurring in small glassy crystals also a constituent of some igneous rocks. It is a lime feldspar. See Feldspar.
n

anorthoclase
A feldspar closely related to orthoclase but triclinic. It is chiefly a silicate of sodium potassium and aluminium. Sp. gr. 2.57 -- 2.60.
n

anorthopia
Distorted vision in which straight lines appear bent.
n

anorthoscope
An optical toy for producing amusing figures or pictures by means of two revolving disks on one of which distorted figures are painted.
n

anorthosite
A granular igneous rock composed almost exclusively of a soda-lime feldspar usually labradorite.
n

anosmia
Loss of the sense of smell.
n

anosmic
of or pertaining to anosmia.
adj

anostraca
an order of small aquatic crustaceans lacking a carapace: fairy shrimps; brine shrimps.

adj

adj

anseres
A Linnaean order of aquatic birds swimming by means of webbed feet as the duck or of lobed feet as the grebe. In this order were included the geese ducks auks divers gulls petrels etc.
n

anseriformes
A division of birds including the geese ducks and closely allied forms.
n

a family name used in some classifications for the swans.

adj

adj

answer
To speak in defense against; to reply to in defense; as to answer a charge; to answer an accusation;  To speak or write in return to as in return to a call or question or to a speech declaration argument or the like; to reply to (a question remark etc.); to respond to;  To respond to satisfactorily; to meet successfully by way of explanation argument or justification and the like; to refute;  To be or act in return or response to;  To render account to or for;  To atone; to be punished for;  To be opposite to; to face;  To be or act an equivalent to or as adequate or sufficient for; to serve for; to repay;  To be or act in accommodation conformity relation or proportion to; to correspond to; to suit;  To speak or write by way of return (originally to a charge) or in reply; to make response; To make a satisfactory response or return; To be or act in return; To be opposite or to act in opposition;  A reply to a charge; a defense; Something said or written in reply to a question a call an argument an address or the like; a reply; Something done in return for or in consequence of something else; a responsive action; A solution the result of a mathematical operation; as the answer to a problem; A counter-statement of facts in a course of pleadings; a confutation of what the other party has alleged; a responsive declaration by a witness in reply to a question. In Equity it is the usual form of defense to the complainant's charges in his bill.
v

answerable
Obliged to answer; liable to be called to account; liable to pay indemnify or make good; accountable; amenable; responsible; as an agent is answerable to his principal; to be answerable for a debt or for damages;  Capable of being answered or refuted; admitting a satisfactory answer;  Correspondent; conformable; hence comparable;  Proportionate; commensurate; suitable; as an achievement answerable to the preparation for it;  Equal; equivalent; adequate.
adj

answerableness
The quality of being answerable liable responsible or correspondent.
n

answerably
In an answerable manner; in due proportion or correspondence; suitably.

n

answerless

adj

ant
A contraction for are and am not; also used for is not; -- now usually written ain't;  A hymenopterous insect of the Linnaean genus Formica which is now made a family of several genera; an emmet; a pismire.

ant-

n

antagonistic
Opposing in combat combating; contending or acting against; as antagonistic forces.

antagonists
muscles having opposite effects; the contraction of one neutralizes the contraction of the other.

adj

antarctic
Opposite to the northern or arctic pole; relating to the southern pole or to the region near it and applied especially to a circle distant from the pole 23° 28′. Thus we say the antarctic pole circle ocean region current etc.
adj

antares
The principal star in Scorpio: -- called also the Scorpion's Heart.
