n

appui
A support or supporter; a stay; a prop;  The mutual bearing or support of the hand of the rider and the mouth of the horse through the bit and bridle.
n

appulse
A driving or running towards; approach; impulse; also the act of striking against;  The near approach of one heavenly body to another or to the meridian; a coming into conjunction; as the appulse of the moon to a star or of a star to the meridian.
n

appulsion
A driving or striking against; an appulse.
n

appulsive
Striking against; impinging; as the appulsive influence of the planets.
adj

appulsively
By appulsion.
adv

appurtenance
That which belongs to something else; an adjunct; an appendage; an accessory; something annexed to another thing more worthy; in common parlance and legal acceptation something belonging to another thing as principal and which passes as incident to it as a right of way or other easement to land; a right of common to pasture an outhouse barn garden or orchard to a house or messuage. In a strict legal sense land can never pass as an appurtenance to land.
n

appurtenances
miscellaneous articles needed for a particular operation or sport etc.
n

appurtenant
Annexed or pertaining to some more important thing; accessory; incident; as a right of way appurtenant to land or buildings;  Something which belongs or appertains to another thing; an appurtenance.
adj

apractic
having uncoordinated muscular movements symptomatic of a CNS disorder; suffering from apraxia.
adj

apraxia
inability to make purposeful movements but without paralysis or loss of sensory function.
n

apraxic
having uncoordinated muscular movements symptomatic of a CNS disorder.
adj

apres-ski
concerned with or designed for use after skiing; occurring after a day of skiing; as apres-ski wear; an apres-ski party;  the time after skiing.
adj

apricate
To bask in the sun.
v

aprication
Basking in the sun.
n

apricot
A fruit allied to the plum of an orange color oval shape and delicious taste; also the tree (Prunus Armeniaca of Linnaeus) which bears this fruit. By cultivation it has been introduced throughout the temperate zone.
n

april
The fourth month of the year;  Fig.: With reference to April being the month in which vegetation begins to put forth the variableness of its weather etc.
n

a-priori
Characterizing that kind of reasoning which deduces consequences from definitions formed or principles assumed or which infers effects from causes previously known; deductive or deductively. The reverse of a posteriori;  Applied to knowledge and conceptions assumed or presupposed as prior to experience in order to make experience rational or possible.
misc

apriorism
An a priori principle.
n

apriority
The quality of being innate in the mind or prior to experience; a priori reasoning.
n

aprocta
A group of Turbellaria in which there is no anal aperture.
n

aproctous
Without an anal orifice.
adj

apron
An article of dress of cloth leather or other stuff worn on the fore part of the body to keep the clothes clean to defend them from injury or as a covering. It is commonly tied at the waist by strings;  Something which by its shape or use suggests an apron;.
n

aproned
Wearing an apron.
adj

apronful
The quantity an apron can hold.
n

apronless
Without an apron.
adj

apron-man
A man who wears an apron; a laboring man; a mechanic.
misc

apron-string
The string of an apron.
misc

apropos
Opportunely or opportune; seasonably or seasonable;  By the way; to the purpose; suitably to the place or subject; -- a word used to introduce an incidental observation suited to the occasion though not strictly belonging to the narration.
adj

apse
A projecting part of a building esp. of a church having in the plan a polygonal or semicircular termination and most often projecting from the east end. In early churches the Eastern apse was occupied by seats for the bishop and clergy;  A reliquary or case in which the relics of saints were kept.
n

apsidal
Of or pertaining to the apsides of an orbit;  Of or pertaining to the apse of a church; as the apsidal termination of the chancel.
adj

apsides
See Apsis.
n

apsis
One of the two points of an orbit as of a planet or satellite which are at the greatest and least distance from the central body corresponding to the aphelion and perihelion of a planet or to the apogee and perigee of the moon. The more distant is called the higher apsis; the other the lower apsis; and the line joining them the line of apsides;  In a curve referred to polar coordinates any point for which the radius vector is a maximum or minimum;  Same as Apse.
n

apsu
father of the gods and consort of Tiamat.
n

apt
Fit or fitted; suited; suitable; appropriate;  Having an habitual tendency; habitually liable or likely; -- used of things;  Inclined; disposed customarily; given; ready; -- used of persons;  Ready; especially fitted or qualified (to do something); quick to learn; prompt; expert; as a pupil apt to learn; an apt scholar;  To fit; to suit; to adapt.
adj

aptable
Capable of being adapted.
adj

aptate
To make fit.
v

aptera
Insects without wings constituting the seventh Linnaen order of insects an artificial group which included Crustacea spiders centipeds and even worms. These animals are now placed in several distinct classes and orders.
n

apteral
Apterous;  Without lateral columns; -- applied to buildings which have no series of columns along their sides but are either prostyle or amphiprostyle and opposed to peripteral.
adj

apteran
One of the Aptera.
n

apteria
Naked spaces between the feathered areas of birds. See Pteryliae.
n

apterous
Destitute of wings; apteral; as apterous insects;  Destitute of winglike membranous expansions as a stem or petiole; -- opposed to alate.
adj

apteryges
An order of birds including the genus Apteryx.
n

apterygiformes
a ratite bird order: flightless ground birds having vestigial wings and long bills and small eyes: kiwis.
n

apteryx
A genus of New Zealand birds about the size of a hen with only short rudiments of wings armed with a claw and without a tail; the kiwi. It is allied to the gigantic extinct moas of the same country. Five species are known.
n

aptitude
A natural or acquired disposition or capacity for a particular purpose or tendency to a particular action or effect; as oil has an aptitude to burn;  A general fitness or suitableness; adaptation;  Readiness in learning; docility; aptness.
n

aptitudinal
Suitable; fit.
adj

aptly
In an apt or suitable manner; fitly; properly; pertinently; appropriately; readily.
adv

aptness
Fitness; suitableness; appropriateness; as the aptness of things to their end;  Disposition of the mind; propensity; as the aptness of men to follow example;  Quickness of apprehension; readiness in learning; docility; as an aptness to learn is more observable in some children than in others;  Proneness; tendency; as the aptness of iron to rust.
n

aptote
A noun which has no distinction of cases; an indeclinable noun.
n

aptotic
Pertaining to or characterized by aptotes; uninflected; as aptotic languages.
adj

aptychus
A shelly plate found in the terminal chambers of ammonite shells. Some authors consider them to be jaws; others opercula.
n

apus
A genus of fresh-water phyllopod crustaceans. See Phyllopod.
n

apyretic
Without fever; -- applied to days when there is an intermission of fever.
adj

apyrexia
The absence or intermission of fever.
n

apyrexial
Relating to apyrexy.
adj

apyrous
Incombustible; capable of sustaining a strong heat without alteration of form or properties.
adj

aqua
Water; -- a word much used in pharmacy and the old chemistry in various signification determined by the word or words annexed.
n

aquacultural
of or pertaining to aquiculture.
adj

aquaculture
the cultivation of aquatic animals such as fish or shellfish or of plants such as seaweed in a controlled and sometimes enclosed body of water. The term includes use of either salt or fresh water. It is a form of agriculture but under water.
adj

aqua-fortis
Nitric acid.
misc

aqualung
an apparatus containing compressed air or other oxygen-gas mixture permitting a person to breathe under water; -- also called a scuba.
n

aquamarine
A transparent pale green variety of beryl used as a gem. See Beryl.
n

aquapuncture
The introduction of water subcutaneously for the relief of pain.
n

aquarelle
A design or painting in thin transparent water colors; also the mode of painting in such colors.
n

aquarellist
A painter in thin transparent water colors.
n

aquarial
Of or pertaining to an aquarium.
adj

aquarian
One of a sect of Christian in the primitive church who used water instead of wine in the Lord's Supper.
n

aquarium
An artificial pond or a globe or tank (usually with glass sides) in which living specimens of aquatic animals or plants are kept.
n

aquarius
The Water-bearer; the eleventh sign in the zodiac which the sun enters about the 20th of January; -- so called from the rains which prevail at that season in Italy and the East.
n

aquatic
Pertaining to water; growing in water; living in swimming in or frequenting the margins of waters; as aquatic plants and fowls;  An aquatic animal or plant; Sports or exercises practiced in or on the water.
adj

aquatical
Aquatic.
adj

aquatile
Inhabiting the water.
adj

aquatint
A kind of etching in which spaces are bitten by the use of aqua fortis by which an effect is produced resembling a drawing in water colors or India ink; also the engraving produced by this method;  to etch in aquatint.
n

aquavit
a Scandinavian liquor usually flavored with caroway seeds; -- also called akvavit.
n

aqueduct
A conductor conduit or artificial channel for conveying water especially one for supplying large cities with water;  A canal or passage; as the aqueduct of Sylvius a channel connecting the third and fourth ventricles of the brain.
n

aqueity
Wateriness.
n

aqueous
Partaking of the nature of water or abounding with it; watery;  Made from or by means of water.
adj

aqueousness
Wateriness.
n

aquifer
an underground bed or layer yielding ground water for wells and springs etc.; as the Oglala aquifer. The water contained in an aquifer may be of great age and in such cases is sometimes called fossil water.
n

aquiferous
Consisting or conveying water or a watery fluid; as aquiferous vessels; the aquiferous system.
adj

aquifoliaceae
a family of widely distributed shrubs and trees.
n

aquiform
Having the form of water.
adj

aquila
A genus of eagles;  A northern constellation southerly from Lyra and Cygnus and preceding the Dolphin; the Eagle.
n

aquilated
Adorned with eagles' heads.
adj

aquilege
a plant of the genus Aquilegia having irregular showy spurred flowers; N temperate regions esp. mountains.
n

aquilegia
a plant of the genus Aquilegia having irregular showy spurred flowers; N temperate regions esp. mountains.
n

aquiline
Belonging to or like an eagle;  Curving; hooked; prominent like the beak of an eagle; -- applied particularly to the nose.
adj

aquilon
The north wind.
n

aquiparous
Secreting water; -- applied to certain glands.
adj

aquitanian
Of or pertaining to Aquitania now called Gascony.
adj

aquose
Watery; aqueous.
adj

aquosity
The condition of being wet or watery; wateriness.
n

ar
Ere; before.
misc

ara
The Altar; a southern constellation south of the tail of the Scorpion;  A name of the great blue and yellow macaw (Ara ararauna) native of South America.
n

arab
One of a swarthy race occupying Arabia and numerous in Syria Northern Africa etc.
n

araba
A wagon or cart usually heavy and without springs and often covered.
n

arabesque
A style of ornamentation either painted inlaid or carved in low relief. It consists of a pattern in which plants fruits foliage etc. as well as figures of men and animals real or imaginary are fantastically interlaced or put together;  Arabian; Relating to or exhibiting the style of ornament called arabesque; as arabesque frescoes.
n

arabesqued
Ornamented in the style of arabesques.
adj

arabian
Of or pertaining to Arabia or its inhabitants;  A native of Arabia; an Arab.
adj

arabic
Of or pertaining to Arabia or the Arabians;  The language of the Arabians.
adj

arabical
Relating to Arabia; Arabic.
adj

arabin
A carbohydrate isomeric with cane sugar contained in gum arabic from which it is extracted as a white amorphous substance;  Mucilage especially that made of gum arabic.
n

arabinose
A sugar of the composition C5H10O5 obtained from cherry gum by boiling it with dilute sulphuric acid.
n

arabism
An Arabic idiom peculiarly of language.
n

arabist
One well versed in the Arabic language or literature; also formerly one who followed the Arabic system of surgery.
n

arable
Fit for plowing or tillage; -- hence often applied to land which has been plowed or tilled;  Arable land; plow land.
adj

araby
The country of Arabia.
n

aracanese
Of or pertaining to Aracan a province of British Burmah.
adj

aracari
A South American bird of the genus Pleroglossius allied to the toucans. There are several species.
n

arace
To tear up by the roots; to draw away.
v

araceous
Of or pertaining to an order of plants of which the genus Arum is the type.
adj

arachnid
An arachnidan.
n

arachnida
One of the classes of Arthropoda. See Illustration in Appendix.
n

arachnidan
One of the Arachnida.
n

arachnidial
Of or pertaining to the Arachnida.
adj

arachnidium
The glandular organ in which the material for the web of spiders is secreted.
n

arachnitis
Inflammation of the arachnoid membrane.
n

arachnoid
Resembling a spider's web; cobweblike;  Pertaining to a thin membrane of the brain and spinal cord between the dura mater and pia mater;  Covered with or composed of soft loose hairs or fibers so as to resemble a cobweb; cobwebby;  The arachnoid membrane; One of the Arachnoidea.
adj

arachnoidal
Pertaining to the arachnoid membrane; arachnoid.
adj

arachnoidea
Same as Arachnida.
n

arachnological
Of or pertaining to arachnology.
adj

arachnologist
One who is versed in or studies arachnology.
n

arachnology
The department of zoology which treats of spiders and other Arachnida.
n

araeometer
See Areometer.
misc

araeostyle
See Intercolumniation.
adj

araeosystyle
See Intercolumniation.
adj

aragonese
Of or pertaining to Aragon in Spain or to its inhabitants.
adj

aragonite
A mineral identical in composition with calcite or carbonate of lime but differing from it in its crystalline form and some of its physical characters.
n

araguato
A South American monkey the ursine howler (Mycetes ursinus). See Howler n. 2.
n

araise
To raise.
v

arak
Same as Arrack.
n

aralia
any of various plants of the genus Aralia; often aromatic plants having compound leaves and small umbellate flowers.
n

araliaceae
a family of mostly tropical trees and shrubs and lianas: ginseng; hedera.
n

aramaean
Of or pertaining to the Syrians and Chaldeans or to their language; Aramaic.
adj

aramaic
Pertaining to Aram or to the territory inhabitants language or literature of Syria and Mesopotamia; Aramaean; -- specifically applied to the northern branch of the Semitic family of languages including Syriac and Chaldee.
adj

aramaism
An idiom of the Aramaic.
n

aranea
a genus of common garden spiders.
n

araneae
an order of arthropods constituting the spiders.
n

araneida
See Araneina.
n

araneidal
relating to or resembling a spider.
adj

araneidan
Of or pertaining to the Araneina or spiders.
adj

araneiform
Having the form of a spider.
adj

araneina
The order of Arachnida that includes the spiders.
n

araneose
Of the aspect of a spider's web; arachnoid.
adj

araneous
Cobweblike; extremely thin and delicate like a cobweb; as the araneous membrane of the eye. See Arachnoid.
adj

arango
A bead of rough carnelian. Arangoes were formerly imported from Bombay for use in the African slave trade.
n

arapaima
A large fresh-water food fish of South America.
n

arara
The palm (or great black) cockatoo of Australia (Microglossus aterrimus).
n

araroba
Goa powder;  A fabaceous tree of Brazil (Centrolobium robustum) having handsomely striped wood; -- called also zebrawood.
n

aration
Plowing; tillage.
n

aratory
Contributing to tillage.
adj

araucaria
A genus of tall conifers of the pine family. The species are confined mostly to South America and Australia. The wood cells differ from those of other in having the dots in their lateral surfaces in two or three rows and the dots of contiguous rows alternating. The seeds are edible.
n

araucariaceae
a family of tall evergreen cone-bearing trees of South America and Australia with broad leathery leaves; in some classifications included in the Pinaceae.
n

araucarian
Relating to or of the nature of the Araucaria. The earliest conifers in geological history were mostly Araucarian.
adj

araujia
small genus of South American evergreen vines.
n

arawn
Lord of Annwfn (the other world; land of fairies).
pn

arb
Someone who engages in arbitrage (who purchases securities in one market for immediate resale in another in the hope of profiting from the price differential); shortened form of arbitrageur.
n

arbalest
A crossbow consisting of a steel bow set in a shaft of wood furnished with a string and a trigger and a mechanical device for bending the bow. It served to throw arrows darts bullets etc.
n

arbalester
A crossbowman.
n

arbiter
A person appointed or chosen by parties to determine a controversy between them;  Any person who has the power of judging and determining or ordaining without control; one whose power of deciding and governing is not limited;  To act as arbiter between.
n

arbitrable
Capable of being decided by arbitration; determinable.
adj

arbitrage
Judgment by an arbiter; authoritative determination;  A traffic in bills of exchange (see Arbitration of Exchange);  the simultaneous or near simultaneous purchase and sale of the same or closely linked securities or commodities in different markets to make a profit on the (often small) differences in price.
n

arbitrager
same as arbitrageur. - someone who engages in arbitrage; i. e. one who purchases securities in one market for immediate resale in another in the hope of profiting from the price differential.
n

arbitrageur
someone who engages in arbitrage; i. e. one who purchases securities in one market for immediate resale in another in the hope of profiting from the price differential.
n

arbitral
Of or relating to an arbiter or an arbitration.
adj

arbitrament
Determination; decision; arbitration;  The award of arbitrators.
n

arbitrarily
In an arbitrary manner; by will only; despotically; absolutely.
adv

arbitrariness
The quality of being arbitrary; despoticalness; tyranny.
n

arbitrarious
Arbitrary; despotic.
adj

arbitrary
Depending on will or discretion; not governed by any fixed rules; as an arbitrary decision; an arbitrary punishment;  Exercised according to one's own will or caprice and therefore conveying a notion of a tendency to abuse the possession of power;  Despotic; absolute in power; bound by no law; harsh and unforbearing; tyrannical; as an arbitrary prince or government.
adj

arbitrate
To hear and decide as arbitrators; as to choose to arbitrate a disputed case;  To decide or determine generally;  To decide; to determine; To act as arbitrator or judge; as to arbitrate upon several reports; to arbitrate in disputes among neighbors; to arbitrate between parties to a suit.
v

arbitration
The hearing and determination of a cause between parties in controversy by a person or persons chosen by the parties.
n

arbitrational
relating to or resulting from arbitration.
adj

arbitrative
of or pertaining to arbitration; relating to or having the authority to arbitrate.
adj

arbitrator
A person or one of two or more persons chosen by parties who have a controversy to determine their differences. See Arbitration;  One who has the power of deciding or prescribing without control; a ruler; a governor.
n

arbitratrix
A female who arbitrates or judges.
n

arbitress
A female arbiter; an arbitratrix.
n

arblast
A crossbow. See Arbalest.
n

arbor
A kind of latticework formed of or covered with vines branches of trees or other plants for shade; a bower;  A tree as distinguished from a shrub; An axle or spindle of a wheel or opinion.
n

arboraceous
abounding in trees.
adj

arborary
Of or pertaining to trees; arboreal.
adj

arborator
One who plants or who prunes trees.
n

arbor-dianae
A precipitation of silver in a beautiful arborescent form.
misc

arboreal
Of or pertaining to a tree or to trees; of nature of trees;  Attached to found in or upon or frequenting woods or trees; as arboreal animals.
adj

arbored
Furnished with an arbor; lined with trees.
adj

arboreous
Having the form constitution or habits of a proper tree in distinction from a shrub;  Pertaining to or growing on trees; as arboreous moss.
adj

arborescence
The state of being arborescent; the resemblance to a tree in minerals or crystallizations or groups of crystals in that form; as the arborescence produced by precipitating silver.
n

arborescent
Resembling a tree; becoming woody in stalk; dendritic; having crystallizations disposed like the branches and twigs of a tree.
adj

arboresque
resembling a tree in form and branching structure.
adj

arboret
A small tree or shrub.
n

arboretum
A place in which a collection of rare trees and shrubs is cultivated for scientific or educational purposes.
n

arborical
Relating to trees.
adj

arboricole
Tree-inhabiting; -- said of certain birds.
adj

arboricultural
Pertaining to arboriculture.
adj

arboriculture
The cultivation of trees and shrubs chiefly for timber or for ornamental purposes.
n

arboriculturist
One who cultivates trees.
n

arboriform
Treelike in shape.
adj

arborist
One who makes trees his study or who is versed in the knowledge of trees.
n

arborization
The appearance or figure of a tree or plant as in minerals or fossils; a dendrite.
n

arborized
Having a treelike appearance.
adj

arborous
Formed by trees.
adj

arbor-vine
A species of bindweed.
misc

arbor-vitae
An evergreen tree of the cypress tribe genus Thuja. The American species is the Thuja occidentalis;  The treelike disposition of the gray and white nerve tissues in the cerebellum as seen in a vertical section.
misc

arbuscle
A dwarf tree one in size between a shrub and a tree; a treelike shrub.
n

arbuscular
Of or pertaining to a dwarf tree; shrublike.
adj

arbustive
Containing copses of trees or shrubs; covered with shrubs.
adj

arbutus
The strawberry tree a genus of evergreen shrubs of the Heath family. It has a berry externally resembling the strawberry; the arbute tree.
n

arc
A portion of a curved line; as the arc of a circle or of an ellipse;  A curvature in the shape of a circular arc or an arch; as the colored arc (the rainbow); the arc of Hadley's quadrant;  An arch;  The apparent arc described above or below the horizon by the sun or other celestial body. The diurnal arc is described during the daytime the nocturnal arc during the night;  To form a voltaic arc as an electrical current in a broken or disconnected circuit.
n

arca
the type genus of the family Arcidae including ark shells and blood clams.
n

arcade
A series of arches with the columns or piers which support them the spandrels above and other necessary appurtenances; sometimes open serving as an entrance or to give light; sometimes closed at the back (as in the cut) and forming a decorative feature;  An arched or covered passageway or avenue.
n

arcaded
Furnished with an arcade.
adj

arcadia
A mountainous and picturesque district of Greece in the heart of the Peloponnesus whose people were distinguished for contentment and rural happiness;  Fig.: Any region or scene of simple pleasure and untroubled quiet.
n

arcadian
Of or pertaining to Arcadia; pastoral; ideally rural; as Arcadian simplicity or scenery;  the dialect of Ancient Greek spoken by Arcadians.
adj

arcane
Hidden; secret.
adj

arcanum
A secret; a mystery; -- generally used in the plural;  A secret remedy; an elixir.
n

arc-boutant
A buttress that stands apart from the main structure and connected to it by an arch; same as flying buttress.
n

arcella
An amoebalike protozoan with a chitinous shell resembling an umbrella.
n

arcellidae
A natural family of soil and freshwater protozoa; cosmopolitan.
pn

arceuthobium
A genus of chiefly American plants parasitic on conifers.
pn

arch
Any part of a curved line;  Usually a curved member made up of separate wedge-shaped solids with the joints between them disposed in the direction of the radii of the curve; used to support the wall or other weight above an opening. In this sense arches are segmental round (i. e. semicircular) or pointed;  Any place covered by an arch; an archway; as to pass into the arch of a bridge;  Any curvature in the form of an arch; as the arch of the aorta;  To cover with an arch or arches; To form or bend into the shape of an arch;  To form into an arch; to curve;  Chief; eminent; greatest; principal; Cunning or sly; sportively mischievous; roguish; as an arch look word lad;  A chief.
n

arch-
A prefix signifying chief as in archbuilder archfiend.
misc

-arch
A suffix meaning a ruler as in monarch (a sole ruler).
misc

archaean
Ancient; pertaining to the earliest period in geological history;  The earliest period in geological period extending up to the Lower Silurian. It includes an Azoic age previous to the appearance of life and an Eozoic age including the earliest forms of life.
adj

archaeography
A description of or a treatise on antiquity or antiquities.
n

archaeolithic
Of or pertaining to the earliest Stone age; -- applied to a prehistoric period preceding the Paleolithic age.
adj

archaeologian
An archaeologist.
n

archaeologic
Relating to archaeology or antiquities; as archaeological researches.
misc

archaeologist
One versed in archaeology; an antiquary.
n

archaeology
The science or study of antiquities esp. prehistoric antiquities such as the remains of buildings or monuments of an early epoch inscriptions implements and other relics written manuscripts etc.
n

archaeopteryx
A fossil bird of the Jurassic period remarkable for having a long tapering tail of many vertebrae with feathers along each side and jaws armed with teeth with other reptilian characteristics.
n

archaeornis
an extinct primitive toothed bird with a long feathered tail and three free clawed digits on each wing.
n

archaeornithes
a subclass of primitive reptilelike fossil birds of the Jurassic or early Cretaceous.
n

archaeostomatous
Applied to a gastrula when the blastopore does not entirely close up.
adj

archaeozoic
Like or belonging to the earliest forms of animal life;  formed in or belonging to the earlier of two divisions of the Precambrian era;  the time from 1.5 billion to 5 billion years ago; the time when the earth's crust formed; a time when only unicellular organisms and the earliest forms of life are present.
adj

archaic
Of or characterized by antiquity or archaism; antiquated; obsolescent.
adj

archaical
Archaic.
adj

archaism
An ancient antiquated or old-fashioned word expression or idiom; a word or form of speech no longer in common use;  Antiquity of style or use; obsoleteness.
n

archaist
Am antiquary;  One who uses archaisms.
n

archaistic
Like or imitative of anything archaic; pertaining to an archaism.
adj

archaize
To make appear archaic or antique.
v

archangel

n

archangelic
Of or pertaining to archangels; of the nature of or resembling an archangel.
adj

archbishop
A chief bishop; a church dignitary of the first class (often called a metropolitan or primate) who superintends the conduct of the suffragan bishops in his province and also exercises episcopal authority in his own diocese.
n

archbishopric
The jurisdiction or office of an archbishop; the see or province over which archbishop exercises archiepiscopal authority.
n

arch-brick
A wedge-shaped brick used in the building of an arch.

A chief butler; -- an officer of the German empire.
n

archchamberlain
A chief chamberlain; -- an officer of the old German empire whose office was similar to that of the great chamberlain in England.

archchancellor
A chief chancellor; -- an officer in the old German empire who presided over the secretaries of the court.
n

archchemic
Of supreme chemical powers.
adj

archdeacon
In England an ecclesiastical dignitary next in rank below a bishop whom he assists and by whom he is appointed though with independent authority.

archdeaconship

n

archeological
of or pertaining to archeology;  related to or dealing with or devoted to archaeology.
adj

archeologist
an anthropologist who studies prehistoric people and their culture.
n

archeology
the branch of anthropology that studies prehistoric people and their cultures. Same as Archaeology etc.
misc

archeopteryx
an extinct primitive toothed bird (Archaeopteryx lithographica) of the Upper Jurassic having a long feathered tail and hollow bones; usually considered the most primitive of all known birds. Same as archaeopteryx.
n

archeozoic
same as archaeozoic;  the time from 1.5 billion to 5 billion years ago when the earth's crust was formed; the time when only unicellular organisms and the earliest forms of life are present. Same as Archaeozoic.
adj

archepiscopal
of or pertaining to an archbishop.
adj

archer
A bowman one skilled in the use of the bow and arrow.
n

archeress
A female archer.
n

archer-fish
A small fish (Toxotes jaculator) of the East Indies; -- so called from its ejecting drops of water from its mouth at its prey. The name is also applied to Chaetodon rostratus.
misc

archership
The art or skill of an archer.
n

archery
The use of the bow and arrows in battle hunting etc;  the art practice or skill of shooting with a bow and arrows;  Archers or bowmen collectively.
n

arches
pl. of Arch n.
n

archespore
same as archesporium. - a primitive cell or group of cells from which a mother cell develops.
n

archesporial
of or pertaining to an archespore.
adj

archesporium
a primitive cell or group of cells from which a mother cell develops.
n

archetypal
Of or pertaining to an archetype; consisting a model (real or ideal) or pattern; original.
adj

archetypally
With reference to the archetype; originally. “Parts archetypally distinct.”.
adv

archetype
The original pattern or model of a work; or the model from which a thing is made or formed;  The standard weight or coin by which others are adjusted;  The plan or fundamental structure on which a natural group of animals or plants or their systems of organs are assumed to have been constructed; as the vertebrate archetype.
n

archetypical
Relating to an archetype; archetypal.
adj

archeus
The vital principle or force which (according to the Paracelsians) presides over the growth and continuation of living beings; the anima mundi or plastic power of the old philosophers.
n

archi-
A prefix signifying chief arch; as architect archiepiscopal. In (Biol.) and (Anat.) it usually means primitive original ancestral; as archipterygium the primitive fin or wing.
misc

archiannelida
A group of Annelida remarkable for having no external segments or distinct ventral nerve ganglions.
n

archiater
Chief physician; -- a term applied on the continent of Europe to the first or body physician of princes and to the first physician of some cities.
n

archibald-wheel
A metal-hubbed wheel of great strength and elasticity esp. adapted for artillery carriages and motor cars.
misc

archiblastula
A hollow blastula supposed to be the primitive form; a coeloblastula.
n

archical
Chief; primary; primordial.
adj

archidiaconal

adj

archiepiscopacy
That form of episcopacy in which the chief power is in the hands of archbishops;  The state or dignity of an archbishop.

archiepiscopal

adj

archiepiscopality
The station or dignity of an archbishop; archiepiscopacy.

The office of an archbishop; an archbishopric.
n

archierey
The higher order of clergy in Russia including metropolitans archbishops and bishops.
n

archil
A violet dye obtained from several species of lichen (Roccella tinctoria etc.) which grow on maritime rocks in the Canary and Cape Verd Islands etc;  The plant from which the dye is obtained.
n

archilochian

n

archimandrite

n

archimedean
Of or pertaining to Archimedes a celebrated Greek philosopher; constructed on the principle of Archimedes' screw; as Archimedean drill propeller etc.
adj

archimedes
An extinct genus of Bryzoa characteristic of the subcarboniferous rocks. Its form is that of a screw.
n

arching
The arched part of a structure;  Hogging; -- opposed to sagging.
n

archipallium
the olfactory cortex of the cerebrum.
n

archipelagic
Of or pertaining to an archipelago;  The Grecian Archipelago or AEgean Sea separating Greece from Asia Minor. It is studded with a vast number of small islands;  Hence: Any sea or broad sheet of water interspersed with many islands or with a group of islands.
adj

archipterygium
The primitive form of fin like that of Ceratodus.
n

n

architeuthis
A genus of gigantic cephalopods allied to the squids found esp. in the North Atlantic and about New Zealand.
n

A keeper of archives or records.
n

archivolt
The architectural member surrounding the curved opening of an arch corresponding to the architrave in the case of a square opening.
n

archlute
A large theorbo or double-necked lute formerly in use having the bass strings doubled with an octave and the higher strings with a unison.
n

archly
In an arch manner; with attractive slyness or roguishness; slyly; waggishly.

The quality of being arch; cleverness; sly humor free from malice; waggishness.

n

arctic
Pertaining to or situated under the northern constellation called the Bear; northern; frigid; as the arctic pole circle region ocean; an arctic expedition night temperature;  The arctic circle; A warm waterproof overshoe.
adj

a stout-bodied broad-winged moth with conspicuously striped or spotted wings; larvae are hairy caterpillars.
n

a family comprising the tiger moths.

the burdock.

a genus of plants including the bearberry; manzanita.

n

n

-ard
The termination of many English words; as coward reynard drunkard mostly from the French in which language this ending is of German origin being orig. the same word as English hard. It usually has the sense of one who has to a high or excessive degree the quality expressed by the root; as braggart sluggard.
misc

ardassine
A very fine sort of Persian silk.
n

ardeidae
a familu of wading birds incuding the herons egrets night herons and bitterns.
n

ardency
Heat;  Warmth of passion or affection; ardor; vehemence; eagerness; as the ardency of love or zeal.
n

ardennes
a wooded plateau in the Champagne-Ardenne region of France; the site of intense fighting in World Wars I and II.
n

ardent
Hot or burning; causing a sensation of burning; fiery; as ardent spirits that is distilled liquors; an ardent fever;  Having the appearance or quality of fire; fierce; glowing; shining; as ardent eyes;  Warm applied to the passions and affections; passionate; fervent; zealous; vehement; as ardent love feelings zeal hope temper.
adj

ardently
In an ardent manner; eagerly; with warmth; affectionately; passionately.
adv

ardentness
Ardency.
n

ardent-spirits
any type of strongly alcoholic beverage prepared by distillation of an alcohol-containing fermented material.
n

ardois-system
A widely used system of electric night signals in which a series of double electric lamps (white and red) is arranged vertically on a mast and operated from a keyboard below.
misc

ardor
Heat in a literal sense; as the ardor of the sun's rays;  Warmth or heat of passion or affection; eagerness; zeal; as he pursues study with ardor; the fought with ardor; martial ardor;  Bright and effulgent spirits; seraphim.
n

arduous
Steep and lofty in a literal sense; hard to climb;  Attended with great labor like the ascending of acclivities; difficult; laborious; as an arduous employment task or enterprise.
adj

arduously
In an arduous manner; with difficulty or laboriousness.
adv

arduousness
The quality of being arduous; difficulty of execution.
n

ardurous
Burning; ardent.
adj

are
The present indicative plural of the substantive verb to be; but etymologically a different word from be or was. Am art are and is all come from the root as;  The unit of superficial measure being a square of which each side is ten meters in length; 100 square meters or about 119.6 square yards.
misc

area
Any plane surface as of the floor of a room or church or of the ground within an inclosure; an open space in a building;  The inclosed space on which a building stands;  The sunken space or court giving ingress and affording light to the basement of a building;  An extent of surface; a tract of the earth's surface; a region; as vast uncultivated areas;  The superficial contents of any figure; the surface included within any given lines; superficial extent; as the area of a square or a triangle;  A spot or small marked space; as the germinative area;  Extent; scope; range; as a wide area of thought.
n

aread
To tell declare explain or interpret; to divine; to guess; as to aread a riddle or a dream;  To read;  To counsel advise warn or direct;  To decree; to adjudge.
v

To raise; to set up; to stir up;  Backward; in or to the rear; behindhand.
v

areca
A genus of palms one species of which (Areca catechu) produces the areca nut or betel nut which is chewed in India and Southeast Asia with the leaf of the Piper Betle and lime.
n

arecidae
one of four subclasses or superorder of Monocotyledones; comprises about 6400 species in 5 families of trees and shrubs and terrestrial herbs and a few free-floating aquatics including: Palmae; Araceae; Pandanaceae: and Lemnaceae.
n

arecoline
An oily liquid substance C8H13O2N the chief alkaloid of the betel nut to which the latter owes its anthelmintic action.

The name is also applied to various fishes of the genus Argentina; A citizen of the Argentine Republic; an Argentinian; Argentina; in this sense usually preceded by the.

argo
The name of the ship which carried Jason and his fifty-four companions to Colchis in quest of the Golden Fleece;  A large constellation in the southern hemisphere called also Argo Navis. In modern astronomy it is replaced by its three divisions Carina Puppis and Vela.
n

argoan
Pertaining to the ship Argo.
adj

argoile
Potter's clay.
n

argol
Crude tartar; an acidulous salt from which cream of tartar is prepared. It exists in the juice of grapes and is deposited from wines on the sides of the casks.
n

argolic
Pertaining to Argolis a district in the Peloponnesus.
adj

argon
A colorless odorless gas occurring in the air (of which it constitutes 0.93 per cent by volume) in volcanic gases etc.; -- so named on account of its inertness by Rayleigh and Ramsay who prepared and examined it in 1894-95. Symbol A; at. wt. 39.9. Argon is condensible to a colorless liquid boiling at -186.1° C. and to a solid melting at -189.6° C. It has a characteristic spectrum. No compounds of it are known but there is physical evidence that its molecule is monatomic. Weight of one liter at 0° C. and 760 mm. 1.7828 g.
n

argonaut
Any one of the legendary Greek heroes who sailed with Jason in the Argo in quest of the Golden Fleece;  A cephalopod of the genus Argonauta;  One of those who went to California in search of gold shortly after it was discovered there in 1848.
n

argonauta
A genus of Cephalopoda. The shell is called paper nautilus or paper sailor.
n

argonautic
Of or pertaining to the Argonauts.
adj

argonautidae
a family of cephalopods represented solely by the genus Argonauta.
n

argonne
an American operation in World War I (1918); American troops under Pershing drove back the German armies which were saved only by the Armistice on November 11.
n

argos
an ancient city in SE Greece; dominated the Peloponnese in the 7th century BC.

argosy

To invent and offer reasons to support or overthrow a proposition opinion or measure; to use arguments; to reason;  To contend in argument; to dispute; to reason; -- followed by with; as you may argue with your friend without convincing him;  To debate or discuss; to treat by reasoning; as the counsel argued the cause before a full court; the cause was well argued; To prove or evince; too manifest or exhibit by inference deduction or reasoning; To persuade by reasons; as to argue a man into a different opinion; To blame; to accuse; to charge with.

n

argument
Proof; evidence;  A reason or reasons offered in proof to induce belief or convince the mind; reasoning expressed in words; as an argument about concerning or regarding a proposition for or in favor of it or against it;  A process of reasoning or a controversy made up of rational proofs; argumentation; discussion; disputation;  The subject matter of a discourse writing or artistic representation; theme or topic; also an abstract or summary as of the contents of a book chapter poem;  Matter for question; business in hand;  The quantity on which another quantity in a table depends; as the altitude is the argument of the refraction;  The independent variable upon whose value that of a function depends;  To make an argument; to argue.
n

The act of forming reasons making inductions drawing conclusions and applying them to the case in discussion; the operation of inferring propositions not known or admitted as true from facts or principles known admitted or proved to be true;  Debate; discussion.
n

argumentative
Consisting of or characterized by argument; containing a process of reasoning; as an argumentative discourse;  Adductive as proof; indicative; as the adaptation of things to their uses is argumentative of infinite wisdom in the Creator;  Given to argument; characterized by argument; disputatious; as an argumentative writer.

To argue or discuss.

argus
A fabulous being of antiquity said to have had a hundred eyes who has placed by Juno to guard Io. His eyes were transplanted to the peacock's tail;  One very vigilant; a guardian always watchful;  A genus of East Indian pheasants. The common species (Argus giganteus) is remarkable for the great length and beauty of the wing and tail feathers of the male. The species Argus Grayi inhabits Borneo.

n

arion
In Greek legend a fabulous horse the offspring of Poseidon by Demeter (or in other accounts Gaea or a harpy) who to escape him had metamorphosed herself into a mare. It was successively owned by Copreus Oncus Heracles and Adrastus. It possessed marvelous powers of speech and its right feet were those of a man.

n

ark
A chest or coffer;  The oblong chest of acacia wood overlaid with gold which supported the mercy seat with its golden cherubs and occupied the most sacred place in the sanctuary. In it Moses placed the two tables of stone containing the ten commandments. Called also the Ark of the Covenant;  The large chestlike vessel in which Noah and his family were preserved during the Deluge. Gen. vi. Hence: Any place of refuge;  A large flatboat used on Western American rivers to transport produce to market.
n

arkansan
a resident of Arkansas.
n

arkansawyer
a resident of Arkansas.
n

arkite
Belonging to the ark.
adj

arkose
A sandstone derived from the disintegration of granite or gneiss and characterized by feldspar fragments.
n

ark-shell
A marine bivalve shell belonging to the genus Arca and its allies.
misc

arles
An earnest; earnest money; money paid to bind a bargain.
n

arm
The limb of the human body which extends from the shoulder to the hand; also the corresponding limb of a monkey;  Anything resembling an arm;  Fig.: Power; might; strength; support; as the secular arm; the arm of the law;  A branch of the military service; as the cavalry arm was made efficient;  To take by the arm; to take up in one's arms; To furnish with arms or limbs; To furnish or equip with weapons of offense or defense; as to arm soldiers; to arm the country; To cover or furnish with a plate or with whatever will add strength force security or efficiency; as to arm the hit of a sword; to arm a hook in angling; Fig.: To furnish with means of defense; to prepare for resistance; to fortify in a moral sense;  To provide one's self with arms weapons or means of attack or resistance; to take arms.
n

armada
A fleet of armed ships; a squadron. Specifically the Spanish fleet which was sent to assail England a. d. 1558.
n

armadillidiidae
a family comrising the pill bugs.
n

armadillidium
the type genus of the Armadillidiidae.
n

armadillo
Any edentate animal if the family Dasypidae peculiar to America. The body and head are incased in an armor composed of small bony plates. The armadillos burrow in the earth seldom going abroad except at night. When attacked they curl up into a ball presenting the armor on all sides. Their flesh is good food. There are several species one of which (the peba) is found as far north as Texas. See Peba Poyou Tatouay.
n

armado
Armada.
n

armageddon
the final decisive battle between the forces of good and evil as foretold in the Apocolypse of Saint John. Also the site of that battle. Used metaphorically for a vast and decisive conflict attended by cataclysmic destruction.
n

armament
A body of forces equipped for war; -- used of a land or naval force;  All the cannon and small arms collectively with their equipments belonging to a ship or a fortification;  Any equipment for resistance.
n

armamentary
An armory; a magazine or arsenal.
n

armature
Armor; whatever is worn or used for the protection and defense of the body esp. the protective outfit of some animals and plants;  A piece of soft iron used to connect the two poles of a magnet or electro-magnet in order to complete the circuit or to receive and apply the magnetic force. In the ordinary horseshoe magnet it serves to prevent the dissipation of the magnetic force;  Iron bars or framing employed for the consolidation of a building as in sustaining slender columns holding up canopies etc;  That moving part of a dynamo or electric generator in which a current is induced by a moving through a magnetic field or in an electric motor the part through which the applied current moves thereby generating torque. The armature usually consists of a series of coils or groups of insulated conductors surrounding a core of iron.
n

armband
a band worn around arm as identification or to indicate mourning;  a band worn around the upper arm.
n

armchair
A chair with arms to support the elbows or forearms.
n

armed
Furnished with weapons of offense or defense; furnished with the means of security or protection;  Furnished with whatever serves to add strength force or efficiency;  Having horns beak talons etc; -- said of beasts and birds of prey.
adj

armenia
a country in the Caucasus formerly a part of the Soviet Union.
n

armenian
Of or pertaining to Armenia;  A native or one of the people of Armenia; also the language of the Armenians; An adherent of the Armenian Church an organization similar in some doctrines and practices to the Greek Church in others to the Roman Catholic.

armeria
a genus of shrubby or herbaceous low-growing evergreen perennials.

armful

adj

armiger
Formerly an armor bearer as of a knight an esquire who bore his shield and rendered other services. In later use one next in degree to a knight and entitled to armorial bearings. The term is now superseded by esquire.
n

armigerous
Bearing arms.
adj

armil

An armil;  A ring of hair or feathers on the legs.

The act of furnishing with or taking arms;  A piece of tallow placed in a cavity at the lower end of a sounding lead to bring up the sand shells etc. of the sea bottom;  Red dress cloths formerly hung fore and aft outside of a ship's upper works on holidays.
n

The religious doctrines or tenets of the Arminians.
n

Power in arms.

A small arm; as an armlet of the sea;  An arm ring; a bracelet for the upper arm;  Armor for the arm.

adj

horseradish.

n

adj

armored
Clad with armor.
adj

armored-cruiser
A man-of-war carrying a large coal supply and more or less protected from the enemy's shot by iron or steel armor. There is no distinct and accepted classification distinguishing armored and protected cruisers from each other except that the first have more or heavier armor than the second.
misc

armored-division
a division of a land army which is equipped with armored vehicles such as tanks or armored personnel carriers.
misc

armorer
One who makes or repairs armor or arms;  Formerly one who had care of the arms and armor of a knight and who dressed him in armor;  One who has the care of arms and armor cleans or repairs them etc.
n

armorial
Belonging to armor or to the heraldic arms or escutcheon of a family.
adj

armoric
Of or pertaining to the northwestern part of France (formerly called Armorica now Bretagne or Brittany) or to its people.
adj

armorican
A native of Armorica.
n

armorist
One skilled in coat armor or heraldry.
n

armor-plated
Covered with defensive plates of metal as a ship of war; steel-clad.
adj

armory
A place where arms and instruments of war are deposited for safe keeping;  Armor; defensive and offensive arms;  A manufactory of arms as rifles muskets pistols bayonets swords;  Ensigns armorial; armorial bearings;  That branch of heraldry which treats of coat armor.
n

armoured
provided with protective covering; -- used of animals. Opposite of unarmored;  same as armor-clad; -- used of persons or things military. Opposite of unarmored.
adj

armourer
an enlisted man responsible for the upkeep of small arms and machine guns etc;  a manufacturer of firearms.
n

armoury
a collection of resources;  all the weapons and equipment that a country has;  a military structure where arms and ammunition and other military equipment are stored and training is given in the use of arms;  a place where arms are manufactured.
n

armozeen
A thick plain silk generally black and used for clerical.
n

armpit
The hollow beneath the junction of the arm and shoulder; the axilla.
n

armrack
A frame generally vertical for holding small arms.
n

arms
Instruments or weapons of offense or defense;  The deeds or exploits of war; military service or science;  Anything which a man takes in his hand in anger to strike or assault another with; an aggressive weapon;  The ensigns armorial of a family consisting of figures and colors borne in shields banners etc. as marks of dignity and distinction and descending from father to son;  The legs of a hawk from the thigh to the foot.
n

armure
Armor;  A variety of twilled fabric ribbed on the surface.
n

army
A collection or body of men armed for war esp. one organized in companies battalions regiments brigades and divisions under proper officers;  A body of persons organized for the advancement of a cause; as the Blue Ribbon Army;  A great number; a vast multitude; a host.
n

army-organization
The system by which a country raises classifies arranges and equips its armed land forces. The usual divisions are: (1) A regular or active army in which soldiers serve continuously with the colors and live in barracks or cantonments when not in the field; (2) the reserves of this army in which the soldiers while remaining constantly subject to a call to the colors live at their homes being summoned more or less frequently to report for instruction drill or maneuvers; and (3) one or more classes of soldiers organized largely for territorial defense living at home and having only occasional periods of drill and instraction who are variously called home reserves (as in the table below) second third etc. line of defense (the regular army and its reserves ordinarily constituting the first line of defense) territorial forces or the like. In countries where conscription prevails a soldier is supposed to serve a given number of years. He is usually enrolled first in the regular army then passes to its reserve then into the home reserves to serve until he reaches the age limit. It for any reason he is not enrolled in the regular army he may begin his service in the army reserves or even the home reserves but then serves the full number of years or up to the age limit. In equipment the organization of the army is into the three great arms of infantry cavalry and artillery together with more or less numerous other branches such as engineers medical corps etc. besides the staff organizations such as those of the pay and subsistence departments.
misc

armyworm
A lepidopterous insect which in the larval state often travels in great multitudes from field to field destroying grass grain and other crops. The common army worm of the northern United States is the noctuid moth (Pseudaletia unipuncta formerly Leucania unipuncta. The name is often applied to other related species as the cotton worm;  the larva of the fungus gnat; -- they march in large companies in regular order.
misc

arna
The wild buffalo of India (Bos or Bubalus arni) larger than the domestic buffalo and having enormous horns.
n

arnatto

arnaut
An inhabitant of Albania and neighboring mountainous regions specif. one serving as a soldier in the Turkish army.
n

arnica
A genus of plants; also the most important species (Arnica montana) native of the mountains of Europe used in medicine as a narcotic and stimulant.
n

arnicin
An active principle of Arnica montana. It is a bitter resin.
n

An alkaloid obtained from the arnica plant.

n

arpent
Formerly a measure of land in France varying in different parts of the country. The arpent of Paris was 4088 sq. yards or nearly five sixths of an English acre. The woodland arpent was about 1 acre 1 rood 1 perch English.

arpentator
The Anglicized form of the French arpenteur a land surveyor.

arrive

n

arrogance
The act or habit of arrogating or making undue claims in an overbearing manner; that species of pride which consists in exorbitant claims of rank dignity estimation or power or which exalts the worth or importance of the person to an undue degree; proud contempt of others; lordliness; haughtiness; self-assumption; presumption.
n

arrogancy
Arrogance.
n

arrogant

n

arrow
A missile weapon of offense slender pointed and usually feathered and barbed to be shot from a bow.
n

arrow-grass
An herbaceous grasslike plant (Triglochin palustre and other species) with pods opening so as to suggest barbed arrowheads.
n

arrowhead
the pointed head or striking tip of an arrow;  An aquatic plant of the genus Sagittaria esp. Sagittaria sagittifolia -- named from the shape of the leaves.
n

arrowheaded
Shaped like the head of an arrow; cuneiform.
adj

arrowroot
A white-flowered west Indian plant of the genus Maranta esp. Maranta arundinacea now cultivated in many hot countries. Its root yields arrowroot starch. It said that the Indians used the roots to neutralize the venom in wounds made by poisoned arrows;  A nutritive starch obtained from the rootstocks of Maranta arundinacea and used as food esp. for children an invalids; also a similar starch obtained from other plants as various species of Maranta and Curcuma.
n

arrow-shaped
like an arrow head without flaring base lobes; -- of a leaf shape.
adj

arrowwood
A shrub (Viburnum dentatum) growing in damp woods and thickets; -- so called from the long straight slender shoots. Also any of several other similar small trees whose straight shoots were used for making arrows.
n

arrow-wood
any plant (Viburnum recognitum) closely related to southern arrow wood; eastern U.S. Maine to Ohio and Georgia.
n

arrowworm
A peculiar transparent worm of the genus Sagitta living at the surface of the sea. See Sagitta.
n

arrowy
Consisting of arrows;  Formed or moving like or in any respect resembling an arrow; swift; darting; piercing.
adj

arroyo
A water course; a rivulet;  The dry bed of a small stream.
n

n
